(Ord. No. 01-20, § 9, 10-16-01)  
ARTICLE IV. - WILDFIRE HAZARD MITIGATION 
 
Sec. 25-101. - Findings. 
The City Council hereby makes the following findings: 
(a)  Palm Coast is a 42,000 acre planned development situated in coastal plain flatwoods. Prior to its development the land was actively managed for southern pine timber production. Timber management included the periodic use of prescribed burns to control vegetative fuel buildup. 
(b)  Palm Coast has a densely developed core, in which homes have been built sporadically throughout the development. Prescribed fires are no longer used for timber management. 
(c)  In May 1985, a wildfire burned through the City destroying 100 homes and damaging 200 others. A study conducted by the Florida Division of Forestry concluded that fire crowning in the pine tree canopy, a buildup of brush within 30 feet of a residential structure, and a general buildup of fuels from decaying vegetation significantly correlated to the destruction or damage of a residential structure. 
(d)  In the summer of 1998 a devastating wildfire again burned through the City due to drought and the accumulation of brush, destroying and damaging many homes and community infrastructure. The same factors were associated with increased fire losses. 
(e)  Fighting fires in the intermix between pine plantation timberlands and rural residential development requires different fire suppression strategies and equipment. Relying on suppression may not be reliable because it is a minor component in determining the loss of property. More important factors are weather conditions, vegetation, structural characteristics and accessibility. 
(f)  Many homeowners and landowners do not or cannot adopt mitigation measures such as brush clearance and fire resistant roofing material. Public education is hampered because the City has a very rapid rate of population growth and a number of the homes in the community are only seasonally occupied. 
(g)  State law authorizes the Florida Division of Forestry to conduct prescribed burns as a mitigation measure on private lands. Such prescribed burning however is of limited utility because of the spreading and scattering of new homes being built in the pine plantation. 
(h)  To further promote hazard mitigation, the City is required to exercise its power in coordination with the State of Florida Division of Forestry, to address wildfire hazard mitigation. Effective hazard mitigation to address the evolution of the City's development from a pine plantation to a residential community includes selective mowing of brush where prescribed burning is not adequate or feasible. 
(i)  The state division of forestry and the City have the capability to identify areas that have a relatively severe risk of wildfire hazard and to prioritize those areas for systematic mitigation planning and implementation. 
(j)  Such systematic mitigation measures are necessary to avoid catastrophic loss to the community economically and in the quality of life. 
(k)  Such systematic mitigation, to the extent it limits wildfire damage, also will help the community conserve its natural resources for aesthetic, environmental and stormwater management purposes. 
(l)  The risk of wildfire recurrence is substantial under expected climatic conditions, weather patterns associated with increased fire activity are a part of the El Nino/La Nina Southern Oscillation phenomena that the City can expect to experience on a recurring basis. As Southern Pacific sea surface temperatures drop, fire activity in Florida increases. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 1, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-102. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings unless a different meaning is clearly intended: 
Brush shall mean plant species that by virtue of their arrangement, chemical composition, and growth pattern provide a ready path for uncontrolled fire to spread. Species included in this definition include saw palmetto, gallberry, fetterbush and wax myrtle. Pine trees less than five inches diameter breast height (four and one-half feet above grade) are included in this definition. 
Fire hazard shall mean brush or other vegetation, which by reason of their nature, location or condition may cause loss, damage, or injury to persons or property by reason of fire. Brush on undeveloped lots averaging over three feet tall within 30 feet of an existing residential structure is considered a fire hazard. 
Lot, tract or parcel includes the adjacent unpaved portions of the street right-of-way, and the property owner's adjacent properties. 
Remedies or corrective measures as referred to in this article, remedies or corrective measures shall include but not be limited to, the City removing the brush located on the property and adjacent street right-of-way, or removing the unlawful fire hazard on the property and adjacent street right-of-way. 
Street shall mean any public street, road, highway, freeway, lane, path, public way or place, sidewalk, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive or easement now or hereafter held by the City for the purpose of public travel. 
Undeveloped vacant lot shall mean any lot or parcel that does not contain a structure and/or improvement. This shall also include adjacent property where both parcels are owned by one person or entity, but only if said adjacent property is located within 200 feet of a developed lot. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 2, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-103. - Designation of hazardous properties. 
The City Manager or designee will identify undeveloped lots determined to constitute a fire hazard. The City Manager or designee shall develop a plan for hazard mitigation for the identified area which shall include public education. The plan may include selective mowing of brush determined to constitute a fire hazard, pursuant to this article. The City shall notify owners of property within the identified area who have fire hazards and shall inform such owners of the action required to be taken. Such properties that contain fire hazards shall be public nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 3, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-104. - Unlawful fire hazard. 
Allowing brush to accumulate on any undeveloped lot, tract or parcel of land shall be unlawful where it is held by the City Manager or designee to constitute a fire hazard under section 25-103, and is hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance. It shall be the owner's responsibility to remedy the violation constituting a fire hazard. This section shall include the property owner's adjacent properties, as well as the adjacent street right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 4, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-105. - Violation to permit unlawful fire hazard. 
Any owner, lessee or occupant of any lot, tract or parcel of land in the City who permits a fire hazard consisting of brush on any undeveloped lot to the extent and in the manner that it creates a fire hazard, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and punished according to law. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 5, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-106. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2005-06, § 2(a), adopted Feb. 1, 2005, repealed § 25-106, which pertained to Fire Mitigation Review Board and derived from Ord. No. 01-11, § 6, adopted April 17, 2001. Ord. No. 2005-06, § 2(b) states: "The duties of the Fire Mitigation Review Board are hereby assigned to the City of Palm Coast Code Enforcement Board with all actions pertaining to fire mitigation being taken in conformity to the provisions of Ordinance Number 2001-11 and the laws, ordinances, rules and procedures applicable to the Code Enforcement Board." At the editor's discretion, in accordance with the provisions of Ord. No. 2005-06, § 5(b), all references within this article to the Fire Mitigation Review Board have been changed to the Code Enforcement Board.  
Sec. 25-107. - Notice by City to owner of record of violation; requirement to remedy violation; copy of notice to owner. 
(a)  If property is designated a fire hazard and a public nuisance, under sections 25-103 and 25-104, a notice shall be given to the owner and/or operator of the property, at their last known address as shown upon the records of the Flagler County Property Appraiser by certified mail or hand delivery. If an attempt to reach the owner and/or operator by hand delivery or certified mail is unsuccessful, the notice shall be given by physical posting on the property in the name of the property owner, as shown upon the records of the Flagler County Property Appraiser, and notice shall also be posted at City Hall and sent by first class mail to the address shown by the property appraiser. 
(b)  The notice to the owner and/or operator shall advise of the condition found to exist on the property described in said notice, and require that the owner either cause such condition to be remedied forthwith, or that the owner authorize the City to have such work done on behalf of the owner at their cost or as a lien against the property. The notice shall detail the specific violations of which the owner is charged, shall detail the specific remedies that are necessary to correct the violations, and shall give the owner 30 calendar days from the date of the notice to remedy the violation. The notice to owner shall provide that the property owner or their agent or representative may request a hearing before the Code Enforcement Board within 30 calendar days of the posting or mailing of the notice by the City, by completing the appropriate form and paying a filing fee of $50.00. This filing fee shall be refunded if the owner is the prevailing party in the action before the Code Enforcement Board as provided in section 25-110. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 7, 4-17-01; Ord. No. 2005-06, § 5, 2-1-05)  
Sec. 25-108. - Failure of owner to mitigate. 
If the owner of the affected property or any agent acting on behalf of the owner thereof fails to request a hearing to protest such action before the Code Enforcement Board before the date specified in the notice to the owner, and fails to take corrective action within the time specified in the aforesaid notice, the City Manager, or designee, may direct the appropriate department of the City to remedy the violation by having the existing condition corrected. Alternatively, the City Manager may refer to the City Attorney to seek an injunction to authorize appropriate mitigation of the fire hazard, including prescribed burns. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 8, 4-17-01; Ord. No. 2005-06, § 5, 2-1-05)  
Sec. 25-109. - Hearing before Code Enforcement Board. 
At the hearing before the Code Enforcement Board, the owner, agent, or representative, may appear before the Code Enforcement Board to show the Code Enforcement Board that the condition mentioned in the notice does not exist, or to show why said brush does not constitute a fire hazard; or why said conditions should not be remedied by the owner, or by the City at the expense of the owner of said property. At said hearing, the City and the property owner may introduce such witnesses as are deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 9, 4-17-01; Ord. No. 2005-06, § 5, 2-1-05)  
Sec. 25-110. - Determination by Code Enforcement Board; time allowance for remedying the violation; appeal. 
(a)  If the property owner or duly authorized agent elects to protest the notice as set forth in the preceding sections and appears before the Code Enforcement Board, the Code Enforcement Board shall determine whether the condition described in sections 25-103 and 25-104 hereof and in the notice to owner does or does not exist. 
(b)  If the Code Enforcement Board determines that the situation and condition as set forth in sections 25-103 and 25-104 and in the notice to owner does not exist, then such notice to owner shall be considered forthwith null and void and of no effect, and no action shall be taken by any agency of the City in regard to such condition at that time, and the filing fee shall be refunded. 
(c)  If the Code Enforcement Board shall determine that the condition described in sections 25-103 and 25-104 and the notice to owner does exist, then from the date of such determination by the Code Enforcement Board, the owner shall have ten calendar days to remedy the violation in accordance with the City's instructions on the notice. Upon the failure of the owner to remedy the violation within the ten calendar days specified, the City Manager, or designee, shall direct the appropriate agency of the City to remedy such violation, as if no protest had been made. 
(d)  Appeal. An appeal shall be to the City Council, and must be taken within five calendar days after an order, decision or determination is made by the Code Enforcement Board. The appeal shall be limited to the record before the Code Enforcement Board. The appeal shall be filed on a form prescribed by the City, and shall be accompanied by a $50.00 filing fee, which shall be refunded if the owner prevails in the appeal. The City Council may, upon appeal, reverse, affirm, or modify any order or determination of the Code Enforcement Board. If the City Council affirms the decision of the Code Enforcement Board, then the owner shall have ten calendar days from date of the City Council hearing to remedy the violation. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 10, 4-17-01; Ord. No. 2005-06, § 5, 2-1-05)  
Sec. 25-111. - Collection of costs and records; secured property. 
After causing the violation to be remedied, the City Manager, or designee, shall certify the expense incurred in remedying the violation, whereupon such expense, plus a charge of $100.00 to cover City administrative expenses, shall become payable within 30 days from completion of the work, after which a special assessment lien and charge will be made upon the property, which shall be payable with interest at the rate allowable by law beginning 30 days from the date of such certification is made until paid. The costs shall include all expenditures by the state division of forestry, the City or their authorized agents for labor, supplies, equipment use, contractors and services related to implementing the mitigation plan for the property and the cost of filing the lien. 
Such lien shall take priority and be enforceable in the same manner as a tax lien in favor of the City, and may be satisfied at any time by payment thereof including accrued interest. Notice of such lien shall be filed in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court and recorded upon the public records of Flagler County, Florida. 
If the subject property is secured by locks or otherwise, the City shall have the authority to enter such property for purposes of remedying the violative condition, and any additional costs incurred by the City in gaining access to the property or in resecuring the property after cleaning shall be considered expenses of remedying the condition. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 11, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-112. - Imminent fire danger. 
Nothing in this article shall prevent the City from taking all actions necessary to fight fires when there is imminent fire danger, including, but not limited to, clearing brush from private property without notice. Nothing in this ordinance shall prevent the City from acting pursuant to F.S. § 590.02, where necessary. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 12, 4-17-01)  
Sec. 25-113. - No tree permit required; other restrictions and requirements applicable. 
No permit shall be required for remedying the violations as required by this article; however, the requirements, restrictions and limitations imposed by other sections of City Code and applicable provisions of the land development code pertaining to environmental preservation, tree removal permits, change of grade, etc., shall be applicable. In the event of any conflict between this section and any other provision of this Code or applicable provision of the land development code, the other sections of this Code or applicable provisions of the land development code shall prevail and govern. 
(Ord. No. 01-11, § 13, 4-17-01)  
ARTICLE V. - SPARKLERS AND FIREWORKS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-22, §§ 1—9, adopted Dec. 5, 2006, amended the Code by adding provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included herein as §§ 25-135—25-143. Former Art. V, § 25-135, pertained to open fires and fireworks, and derived from Ord. No. 2004-12, § 1, adopted June 1, 2004. 
 
Sec. 25-135. - Authority. 
This article is enacted pursuant to the Home Rule Charter of Palm Coast and Chapter 791, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 1, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-136. - Short title. 
This article shall be known as and may be cited as the "City of Palm Coast Fireworks Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 2, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-137. - Intent. 
The purpose and intent of this article is to promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, welfare and quality of life of the citizens of the City of Palm Coast, Florida by establishing regulations governing the sale, purchase and utilization of fireworks and sparklers within the City. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 3, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-138. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms shall have the meanings set out below, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
Fire district means the City Fire Rescue Department, or any corporations, including Flagler County, with whom the City contracts for fire protections services. 
Fire District Official means the City Fire Chief or designee. 
Fireworks means and includes any combustible or explosive composition or substance or combination of substances, or unless otherwise exempt, any articles prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration, or detonation. The term includes blank cartridges and toy cannons in which explosives are used, firecrackers, torpedoes, skyrockets, roman candles, dago bombs, or any fireworks containing any explosives or flammable compound or any tablets or other device containing any explosive substance. "Fireworks" does not include any item listed in Section 791.04(4)(c), Florida Statutes. 
Manufacturer means any person, firm, partnership, or corporation engaged in the manufacture or construction of sparklers or fireworks in the City. 
Proximate audience means an audience to an indoor display and which is closer to pyrotechnic devices than allowed by National Fire Protection Association (N.F.P.A.) Code 1123, 1995 Edition. 
Pyrotechnic operator means the person responsible for pyrotechnic safety and who controls, initiates, or otherwise creates special effects. The operator is also responsible for storing, setting up and removing pyrotechnic material or devices after a performance. 
Pyrotechnic means the science of controlled exothermic chemical reactions that are timed to create the effects of heat, gas, sound, dispersion of aerosols, emission of visible electromagnetic radiation, or a combination of these effect to provide the maximum effect from least volume. 
Pyrotechnic material means a chemical mixture used in the entertainment industry to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation. Such chemical mixture predominately consists of solids capable of producing a controlled, self-sustaining, and self-contained exothermic chemical reaction that results in heat, gas, sound, light, or a combination of these effects. The chemical reaction functions without external oxygen. 
Retailer means any person, firm, partnership, or corporation who at a fixed place of business, is engaged in the business of selling sparklers to consumers at retail. 
Seasonal retailer means any person, firm, partnership, or corporation engaged in the business of selling sparklers at retail from June 20 through July 5 and from December 10 through January 2 of each year from a temporary location (including, but not limited to, tents, storefronts and open air sales). 
Sparkler means a device which emits showers of sparks upon burning, does not contain any explosive compound, does not detonate or explode, is hand-held or ground-based, cannot propel itself through the air, and contains nor more than 100 grams of chemical compound which produces sparks upon burning. Any sparkler that is not approved by the State Fire Marshal is classified as fireworks. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 4, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-139. - Storage and sale of sparklers; registration and permit required. 
(a)  Sparklers shall be stored and sold in the City in accordance with the zoning laws, fire prevention code, license laws of the City and permits issued by the Fire District Official or State Division of Fire Marshal having jurisdiction and all other State and local laws. 
(b)  All manufacturers, distributors, retailers, seasonal retailers and wholesalers of sparklers shall show proof of current registration with the State Division of Fire Marshal to the Fire District Official upon request. 
(c)  All manufacturers, distributors, wholesalers, retailers, and seasonal retailers of sparklers must obtain an annual permit from the City prior to selling sparklers in the City. 
(d)  A retailer or seasonal retailer who sells sparklers at more than one retail location may submit one permit application for all locations within the City by providing the address of each location on the same permit application form, or the retailer may submit multiple application forms for each location. 
(e)  Nothing herein shall be construed to exempt manufacturers, distributors, wholesalers, retailers or seasonable retailers, from compliance with all other applicable zoning, licensing, building and fire protection requirements of the City. 
(f)  It is prohibited and unlawful to sell sparklers in the City without a permit. 
(g)  Each retailer and seasonal retailer shall keep a copy of the permit and state registration at every location where sparklers are sold. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 5, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-140. - Prohibition of fireworks; exceptions; permits and regulations. 
(a)  Except as provided in Sections 791.02, 791.04, or 791.07, Florida Statutes, it is prohibited and unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, or corporation to offer for sale at wholesale or retail, expose for sale at wholesale or retail, or use or explode any fireworks within the City without a City permit. 
(b)  The City Manager, or designee, shall develop an affidavit which all sellers of fireworks within the City shall use to determine the entitlement of any purchaser at retail or wholesale to buy fireworks. 
(c)  The purchaser of any fireworks must furnish to the seller, at the time of sale, proof of identification, and if applicable, proof that the purchaser in compliance with Chapter 791, Florida Statutes. The seller shall retain a copy of any proof of registration presented. 
(d)  The seller shall maintain a permanent on-site record of all sales, including the name and address of each purchaser, the form of the purchaser's identification presented along with any unique identifier associated with that identification (e.g., drivers license number), and, where required, proof of registration and compliance with Chapter 791, Florida Statutes. If the seller determines that registration under Chapter 791, Florida Statutes, is not required, then the basis for such exception or exemption shall be recorded on a form approved by the Fire District Official. 
(e)  Any person, firm, partnership, or corporation who is not registered with the Division of the State Fire Marshal and who, pursuant to Section 791.04, Florida Statutes, purchases fireworks for shipment directly out of the State, is prohibited from taking possession of such fireworks. The seller shall retain the possession of such fireworks and shall be responsible for shipping all fireworks purchased to the purchaser or other recipient at any out-of-State point of delivery. If an out-of-State address is not given to seller for shipment the sale shall be presumed to be unlawful under Section 791.04, Florida Statues, as a not for out-of-State use sale and is prohibited. 
(f)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity to sell fireworks for out-of-State use and deliver possession of said fireworks to the purchaser by any means other than by shipping the fireworks to the out-of-State delivery address. 
(g)  Any person, firm, partnership or corporation who, pursuant to rules promulgated by the Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services under Section 791.07, Florida Statutes, purchases fireworks for frightening birds must provide to the seller documentary evidence, stamped by the Flagler County Sheriff's Office, the City Fire District Office or other City designee, that the purchaser has complied with the regulations of the State Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services and that the purchaser has filed with the Sheriff of the County where the fireworks will be used the statement as required by the Florida Administrative Code. The purchaser shall provide to the seller a copy of any statement so filed with the Sheriff as required by the Florida Administrative Code. The seller shall maintain a copy of the proof offered in addition to the information required in subsection (e) above. 
(h)  The purchaser of fireworks to be used by a railroad or other transportation agency shall provide a copy of the business license or other government issued document evidencing that the purchaser is a legitimate railroad or transportation agency. A commercial driver's license, by itself, does not meet the requirements of this section. A copy of this document shall be maintained by the seller. 
(i)  The purchaser of fireworks to be used in quarrying or for blasting or other industrial use must produce a copy of the quarry or mine permit or business license or other governmentally issued document showing that the purchaser is operating a mine, quarry or other industrial enterprise. The seller shall maintain a copy of this proof and note the use for which the fireworks shall be used. The seller shall also record the location where the fireworks will be used. The purchaser of fireworks to be used in a public display must produce a copy of the current permit from a county or municipality and the seller must keep a copy of this permit with the record of sale. 
(j)  All appropriate local and State permits, registration, certificates and licenses must be displayed at each retail, wholesale, distributing, or manufacturing site. 
(k)  The seller shall maintain copies of the records required by this article at the location where the sale took place for a period of four years from the date of the sale. If the location of the sale was in a temporary facility, the records shall be maintained at that site for the duration of the existence of the temporary facility and thereafter for the remainder of the four years in a location within the City which location shall be listed on the application for City permit. These records shall be available and provided immediately upon request for inspection by Fire District Official or Law Enforcement. In the event that the sales location, other than a temporary site, closes or moves, the records required by this section to be retained shall be stored at a location in the City where they will be readily available for inspection by the Fire District Official, the City or its designee. The seller shall advise the City of any change in the location of these records. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 6, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-141. - Use of fireworks. 
It is prohibited and unlawful for a person or entity to use, explode, or store, fireworks in the City, unless: 
(1)  The person or entity first obtains all appropriate permits for the display of fireworks or pyrotechnics; or 
(2)  The use is by a railroad or other transporting agency for illumination or signal purposes or the use is associated with quarrying, blasting, or another industrial purpose in accordance with Section 791.04, Florida Statutes; or 
(3)  The use in conjunction with a bona fide agricultural use, as provided in Section 791.07, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 7, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-142. - Display of fireworks. 
(a)  The supervised public display of fireworks, as contemplated in Section 791.02, Florida Statutes, is permitted if the requirements of this section have been met. All displays must be in accordance with the Code for the Display of Fireworks, as set out in NFPA Code 1123 and NFPA Code 1126, 1995 Edition. 
(b)  An application for a permit to operate a display of fireworks in accordance with this article shall be made with the Fire District Official at least 15 days prior to the scheduled date of the event. The application shall be in a form prepared by the City. 
(c)  Evidence of financial responsibility in the form of proof of insurance at a type and level approved by the City's Risk Manager shall be provided to the City at the time of application. 
(d)  Application and payment fees shall be established by resolution adopted by the City Council. 
(e)  The Fire District Official or designee will determine if the display of fireworks, as proposed by the applicant, will provide an acceptable degree of life safety based upon the terrain, available fire protection features or other requirements deemed appropriate by the Fire District Official. 
(f)  The Fire Official District Official may, as a condition of the permit, require on-site uniformed district personnel, specialized fire protection equipment or extra suppression equipment. Any costs incurred to comply with the conditions of the permit will be the responsibility of the applicant. 
(g)  A permit may be revoked by the Fire Marshal, Fire District Official or their designee at any time if the permittee fails to comply with the terms and conditions of the permit. 
(h)  Permits are not transferable. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 8, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-143. - Penalties and enforcement. 
The City may enforce the provisions of this article by any means permitted by law and the penalty for violation of this article shall be the maximum permitted by State law. 
(Ord. No. 06-22, § 9, 12-5-06)  
Sec. 25-144. - Use of fireworks and sparklers during fire bans. 
During periods of Flagler County issued fire bans, the sale, use, and/or discharge of fireworks and sparklers are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2008-08, § 1, 6-3-08)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL  
Chapter 27 - FRANCHISE REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL  
ARTICLE II. - CATV SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 27-31. - Short title. 
This division shall be known as the "City of Palm Coast Master Cable TV Regulatory Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-32. - Purposes. 
The purpose of this article is to establish the procedures and criteria for the granting and renewal of nonexclusive cable television franchises within the City. This article further establishes the minimum standards for installation and operation of such franchises, and supplements the standards for existing cable operators. This division additionally protects and controls the use of public easements and rights-of-way by cable TV operators. These criteria and standards are enacted to promote the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City residing in the unincorporated area of the City, and to assure compliance with applicable state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-33. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Cable TV system means a system of antennae, cables, wires, lines, towers, wave guides, fiber optics, conductors, converters, equipment or other facilities designed, constructed or wired for the purpose of transmitting audio signals, digital signals or visual images to and from persons and subscribers in the franchise area, except systems exempted by state law under F.S. § 166.046. 
Gross revenue means any and all compensation and other consideration derived directly by a franchise operator from subscribers for cable TV service including, but not limited to, installation fees, disconnect and reconnect fees, and fees for cable service paid by subscribers. 
Transfer means any sale, conveyance, gift or other disposition of any right, title or interest in a franchise. Any material change in the persons constituting the controlling interest of the franchise operator, for example, shareholders, shall be deemed a transfer. Transfers shall not include assignments by cable operators of their franchises to any entity that is a parent, subsidiary, or affiliate corporation of the cable operator; provided such corporation existed as of the date of the initial franchise authorization for the cable operator, or, if not, that the new subsidiary corporation receives all of the assets of the franchise holder and the same is certified to the City by a senior official of the franchise holder. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-34. - Necessity of franchise. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or operate a cable TV system in the City, excluding the area of its municipalities, without a franchise granted by the City. The issuance of a franchise shall authorize the cable TV operator to install, construct, maintain and operate a cable TV system under, over, through, across, and upon the public easements and rights-of-way in the City, subject to the requirements and restrictions provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-35. - Construction of system. 
(a)  No construction shall take place within City rights-of-way or property without the prior written approval of the City Manager or designee. 
(b)  The franchise operator shall file with the City Manager or designee for approval plans and specifications for the location or relocation of all facilities within the franchise area. Such facilities shall be located or relocated so as not to obstruct or interfere with the use of streets, alleys, easements and other public ways and places, or other utilities or structures already installed or hereafter to be installed, subject at all times to the lawful police power of the City. Street or pavement cuts to install conduit are prohibited unless the franchise operator obtains prior approval from the City Manager or designee according to the procedures and standards of the City's utility accommodation ordinance. 
(c)  The franchise operator may make attachments to poles already in existence within the City. To the extent existing poles are insufficient for its purposes or if the cable operator is unable to negotiate agreements satisfactory to it for use of existing poles, the cable operator may erect its own poles or underground conduit as necessary for the construction and maintenance of its cable TV system, subject to the approval of the City Manager or designee for all such poles or conduit to be placed within City right-of-way or City property. No poles, however, shall be allowed or installed by the cable operator in areas or neighborhoods where utilities are placed below ground. The use of City poles, towers or other electrical facilities owned by the City, if authorized by the City Manager or designee, shall not interfere with the use of such poles, towers or electrical facilities. 
(d)  All underground conduit in City rights-of-way or property shall have a minimum cover of 24 inches below ground and 30 inches below pavement. Crossings of storm drains shall be under the pipe or structure with a minimum clearance of 12 inches below the bottom of the storm drain pipe. All underground conduit off City rights-of-way to a subscriber shall be a minimum of 12 inches below ground, unless the subscriber consents otherwise in writing to less than 12 inches. Such writing need not be a formal document but may be a form used by the cable operator so long as the document establishes that the subscriber or his or her agent consents to a depth of less than 12 inches. 
(e)  All construction, installation, maintenance and repair shall conform to City building codes and ordinances, including but not limited to the tree protection provisions of the City's land development regulations, road damage ordinance and utility accommodation ordinance. 
(f)  All construction, installation and repair work shall be carried out with due regard for safety to surrounding property, whether public or private. The franchise operator shall employ safety measures relating to traffic, whether pedestrian or vehicular, during such work which are consistent with Series 600 of the Florida Department of Transportation, Standard Index, or the Uniform Traffic Control Device Manual, whichever is more stringent. Any use of safety barricades shall conform to the Uniform Traffic Control Device Manual. The franchise operator shall be responsible for any damage to bridges, sidewalks, inlets and drainage structures caused by its operations. Such damage must be repaired according to current standards. Any damage to pavement due to the franchise operator's work must be repaired by the operator with a permanent paved patch, in accordance with current standards, within five working days after the work is completed. 
(g)  All construction, installation, maintenance or repair work shall be conducted in a manner that minimizes the disruption of telephone, electric, gas, water, sewer, cable or other utility services. The franchise operator shall provide reasonable notice to the providers of such services so existing systems can be marked. 
(h)  In the performance of such work, the franchise operator shall insure that the safety, functioning and appearance of the property worked on is not adversely affected. Any property that sustains alteration or damage by reason of the construction, installation, maintenance or repair of the cable TV system shall be restored to its immediate preexisting condition, reasonably and promptly, subject to any device or equipment installed. In the event restoration is not accomplished promptly, the franchise operator shall fully and promptly compensate the owner for such damage. 
(i)  If during the term of the franchise, the City elects to alter or modify the grade or use of any City road, right-of-way or property, the franchise operator, on reasonable notice by the City, shall remove or relocate, permanently or temporarily as the circumstances require, the affected facility or equipment at the operator's expense. 
(j)  All construction, installation, maintenance or repair work shall further conform to any requirements of the State of Florida and the Federal Communications Commission. 
(k)  All obligations provided above shall apply to the employees, agents or independent contractors working for the franchise operator. The franchise operator shall be liable to assure that its employees, agents or independent contractors perform their work in accordance with this regulatory ordinance. This provision shall not be construed to create liability on the part of the cable operator to third parties. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-36. - Design and operation. 
(a)  The cable TV system shall be designed and operated so as to meet all FCC requirements. Franchise operators also are specifically subject to F.S. §§ 337.401, 337.402, 337.403, 337.404 (relating to use of right-of-way, repair to public roads and relocations); F.S. § 166.046 (cable TV franchising requirements); F.S. § 177.091(29) (prohibiting interference with other utility systems, responsibility for damage to other public utilities, and construction requirement to meet National Electrical Code); and such other Florida Statutes or their successors, as may apply to a franchise operator. 
(b)  Franchise operators shall make available and be capable of initially transmitting at least 30 channels for delivery to subscribers upon commencement of operation. This provision shall not be construed to require a franchise operator to carry, at no charge, a signal for a television station which received remuneration from or on behalf of the recipient of the signal (including signals now known as "Teletext" or "Extravision" or other similar programs) for which a charge is made by the television station. 
(c)  To the extent required by the FCC or federal law, a franchise operator shall designate channel capacity for commercial use by persons who are not affiliated with the operator. A franchise operator may use any unused channel capacity designated pursuant to this section until an agreement is reached to lease that capacity. If a person who is not affiliated with a franchise operator seeks to lease channel capacity pursuant to this section, then a franchise operator shall establish the price, terms, and conditions of such lease, which will be at least sufficient to assure that the lease will not adversely affect the operation, financial condition, or market development of the cable system. 
(d)  Franchise operators shall provide one exterior cable service connection outlet for basic service, without installation or monthly charges, to all public schools, all public libraries, all City-owned recreational buildings, the City courthouses and annexes, and all other buildings and facilities owned by the City and used by the City for the delivery of City services to the public; provided that such facilities are within the franchise area of the franchise operator, such facility is contiguous to any main lateral cable system of the operator, and the connections are specifically requested by the City Manager or designee. 
(e)  At the request of the City Manager or designee, franchise operators shall provide the City without charge, one operative television channel over the system. This channel is to be provided solely for the City and other governmental bodies within the City in order to transmit civic and school programs, lectures, shows, announcements, City meetings, or meetings of their committees, educational, amusement or recreational information and all other lawful news information which the City desires at any and all times. All such use of this channel shall be coordinated among the various government entities served by the system. Such coordination shall be through the City Manager or designee. 
(f)  Franchise operators shall furnish the City, free of charge, an emergency override capability and alert warning system by which City officials may interrupt by audio or visual (crawl message) or similar methods all cable system programs simultaneously to either broadcast emergency information directly or to direct viewers to tune to a specified channel. 
(g)  Except to the extent otherwise authorized by law, no monitoring of a terminal connected to the cable system shall be permitted by a franchise operator without the written authorization of the person to be monitored; provided, that this section does not prohibit maintenance and testing procedures designed to assure compliance with technical standards, or to detect unauthorized reception of a signal. 
(h)  All franchise operators shall conduct annual tests of their cable systems at their expense to insure that the system meets all technical guideline standards prescribed by the FCC. A franchise operator shall be responsible for ensuring full compliance with such standards. 
(i)  The franchise operator shall provide the City an accurate map showing the location of all facilities erected, constructed and maintained by the operator. Such maps may be on a scale of one inch equals 100 feet. Such maps are intended to only show locations and not proprietary information as to the technical specifications of the lines. Updated maps shall be furnished to the City Manager or designee on an annual basis. 
(j)  Access to cable service shall not be denied to any group of potential residential cable subscribers by a cable operator because of the income of the residents of the local area in which the group resides. A cable operator may not decline to extend service to a developed neighborhood where it has already extended its cable lines to an adjacent undeveloped neighborhood that, for example, is a new model community. Such an extension shall only be required if there is at least a density of 30 homes per linear mile on a proratable basis; for example, nine homes within three-tenths of a mile from existing plant. This provision shall not require a cable company to extend service to an area already served by another cable operator. There, further, shall be no discrimination among an operator's subscribers for basic cable service. Nothing herein shall be construed to preclude competitive pricing and marketing offers that are not otherwise in violation of local, state or federal law. 
(k)  Whenever it is necessary to shut off or interrupt service for the making of repairs, installations, or adjustments, the franchise operator shall do so at such times as will cause the least amount of inconvenience to its subscribers. Unless such interruption is unforeseen and immediately necessary, the operator will give reasonable notice thereof to its subscribers. The franchise operator shall prorate each subscriber's monthly charge for an interruption of services due to a system shutdown not the fault of the subscriber. Proration will be granted at the request of the subscriber pursuant to section 27-37. 
(l)  The franchise operator shall so operate its system that there will be no interference with television or radio reception through individually owned receiving antennas. The franchise operator will investigate any claim of interference to the television reception of nonsubscribers which might be attributable to the system. If the interference is determined to be attributable to the system, the operator shall make correction promptly. 
(m)  No franchise operator may utilize negative option billing for service, channels or programs to obtain fees from subscribers or potential subscribers. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-37. - Subscriber complaint procedure. 
(a)  All franchise operators shall establish procedures for receiving, acting upon and resolving subscriber complaints which shall comply at least with all FCC requirements and the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Such procedures shall be filed with the City Manager or designee, who is hereby made the designated City official under FCC requirements to administer the City's internal complaint procedures. Notice of the complaint procedures shall be furnished by the operator to its subscribers, including credit procedures for loss of service. The notice shall be given at the time of initial subscription to the system by the subscriber. 
(c)  All franchise operators shall maintain a local telephone with a listed number to receive subscriber complaints by at least an answering service or machine to record complaints on a 24-hour basis. The franchise operator shall promptly respond to such complaints, including those made in writing. 
(d)  The franchise operator shall maintain all written complaints made by subscribers and the action taken by the operator in response. Such records shall be maintained for a period of three years and shall be made available to the City for inspection. 
(e)  Any continuous total outage of a subscriber's service not attributable to the subscriber or his or her equipment which lasts at least 24 hours or more shall be credited for the outage pro rata by the franchise operator for the subscriber's billing if requested by the subscriber. Such credit shall be applied to the subscriber's next billing statement. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-38. - Applications for franchise. 
(a)  A person applying for a franchise, renewal of a franchise, or a transfer of a franchise, shall complete the forms required and pay any pertinent application fee which shall be set by resolution of the City Council. 
(b)  Completed applications shall be submitted to the City Manager or designee, who in turn will schedule the application for the City Council at a duly advertised public hearing. 
(c)  The City Council shall grant applications by a separate franchise agreement which shall include identifying information from the application, insurance requirements, effective date of the franchise and such other terms as the City Council may require. 
(d)  The terms for a franchise or a renewal of a franchise shall be for ten years. 
(e)  Franchise operators shall pay to the City a franchise fee of three percent per calendar year on the operator's gross subscriber revenue. Payment of the franchise fee shall be made by March 31 for the preceding calendar year to the City Manager or designee. The payment shall be accompanied by a sworn statement of the operator's chief financial officer or a certification by an independent certified public accountant that the gross revenues have been correctly tabulated for the franchise. Untimely payments shall be assessed a late charge of one and one-half percent per month on the amount due for each month or portion thereof that full payment has not been made. The failure to make full payment, including any late charges by June 30 shall result in a public hearing on termination of the operator's franchise after notice to the operator. A duly authorized agent of the City shall have the right, power and authority to inspect and audit the operator's records to assess the accuracy of the franchise fee paid or owed. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00) 
Editor's note— Section 3 of Ord. No. 00-20, adopted March 14, 2000, states: This ordinance creates no further vested rights, and the City Council reserves the full prerogative to review, revise, amend and update its regulation of cable television franchises, whether to comport with amendments to federal law or otherwise, at or before the expiration of this ordinance. 
Further, section 4 of said ordinance states: section 27-37(e) is modified to provide for the payment of a franchise fee in the maximum amount permitted by law.  
Sec. 27-39. - Indemnification and insurance. 
(a)  Franchise operators shall indemnify, defend and hold harmless the City and its officers, employees and agents from all claims, damages, taxes, costs, expenses, attorney's fees, paralegal fees, expert witness fees, consultant fees, litigation expenses and any other liability of any kind arising from, in connection with, or as a result of the construction, installation, operation, maintenance, repair or any other cable TV activity associated with the franchise. Excepted from this indemnification is any liability of the City specifically and solely related to its own programming on a governmental access channel and to its actions in interrupting a broadcast to utilize its emergency override capability. The provisions of this indemnification shall survive the operator's franchise for claims arising during the term of the franchise. 
(b)  The franchise operator shall maintain in full force and effect during the life of any franchise public liability insurance and worker's compensation insurance in amounts as specified in the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-40. - Compliance review of franchise. 
(a)  In the event that a present or future franchise operator is in violation of this article, its franchise agreement or a pre-existing franchise ordinance if applicable, such violation shall be handled as follows: 
(1)  The City Manager or designee shall specify the violation in writing to the franchise operator. 
(2)  The operator shall correct the violation promptly or inform the City, in writing, why it believes no violation exists or presents its justification, in writing, for the action or practice. If after 30 days from the notice of violation by the City, the franchise operator has not corrected the violation or the City does not accept the operator's reasons for believing there is no violation, the matter will be scheduled for public hearing before the City Council for the purpose of determining what action, if any, is to be taken with respect to the franchise. 
(3)  The City Council may, in its sole discretion, impose reasonable sanctions, or prescribe reasonable remedial plans, or take other reasonable action to condition the continued validity of the franchise. The City Council also may determine, in its sole discretion, to terminate the franchise for a material violation. 
(b)  The City Council may take immediate action at a public hearing if a franchise operator becomes subject to any court order concerning involuntary bankruptcy, insolvency, or other similar law adversely affecting its credit worthiness; commences a voluntary case under the federal bankruptcy laws, or other federal or state insolvency, or similar laws adversely affecting its credit worthiness; and has made a false representation as to a material fact to the City in its franchise application or a material misrepresentation in its communications with or payments to the City. 
(c)  A franchise operator shall not be deemed to be in violation of this article, its franchise agreement or a pre-existing franchise ordinance if applicable, where the alleged noncompliance is caused by labor strikes, power outages, acts of God or other events outside of the operator's ability to control. 
(d)  All remedies provided herein shall be cumulative and in addition to any other remedy provided by law. No delay or failure by the City to exercise any right shall constitute a waiver of such right. 
(e)  In the event the City must prosecute or defend against litigation, judicial or administrative, to enforce the terms of this article, a pre-existing franchise ordinance, or the franchise agreement against the franchise operator, and the City prevails, the operator shall be liable for the City's legal costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, whether through in-house attorneys or outside counsel, and litigation expenses of every kind, including paralegal, expert witness and consultant fees. This provision shall survive any termination of an operator's franchise for claims arising during the terms of the franchise. 
(f)  Venue for any actions involving this article, a preexisting franchise ordinance or a franchise agreement shall be in the circuit or City court depending on the rules of jurisdiction of said courts, or in the federal district court in which the City is located to the extent concurrent jurisdiction is conferred by the Federal Cable Communications Act or its successor or any applicable federal statute. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
Sec. 27-41. - Supplementing existing franchises. 
All existing cable TV franchises shall remain in effect but shall be subject to the standards, terms and conditions contained in this article. Such additional standards, terms and conditions, except for the duration of the franchise and the franchise fee, shall prevail over any inconsistent provision of any existing ordinance granting a franchise for cable TV. A confirming franchise agreement will be issued to each such cable TV operator within 60 days after the effective date of this article, which shall include the procedures for payment of the franchise fee, public liability and worker's compensation insurance requirements, inspections and audit authority for payment of the franchise fee, and such other terms as are appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1, 3-14-00)  
ARTICLE III. - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-18, §§ 1—42, adopted Oct. 17, 2006, amended the Code by adding provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included herein as §§ 27-51—27-92. 
 
Sec. 27-51. - Intent and purposes. 
The purposes of this article are to: 
(1)  Protect the public health, safety and welfare; 
(2)  Provide for the granting of one or more franchises to permit the use of City streets and other public ways for cable communication systems; 
(3)  Provide for the regulation by the City of the erection, construction, reconstruction, installation, operation, maintenance, dismantling, testing, repair and use of cable communication systems in, upon, along, across, above, over and under or in any manner connected with the streets or other public ways within the City, as it now or in the future may exist; 
(4)  Provide for the payment of fees and other valuable considerations to the City for the use of City streets and other public ways by cable communication systems as well as to compensate the City for costs associated with such use; 
(5)  Provide for the development of cable communication systems as a means to improve communications and serve the present and future needs of the citizens, government and private and public institutions, organizations and enterprises of the City; 
(6)  Provide remedies and prescribe penalties for violations of this article and any franchise agreements executed pursuant to this article; and 
(7)  Provide for a level playing field for all companies providing service. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 1, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-52. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivation shall have the meaning given herein: 
Basic service means service tiers which include the delivery of local broadcast stations, and access channels. The basic service does not include optional program tiers, a la carte services, per channel, per program, or auxiliary services for which a separate charge is made. However, franchisee may include other signals on the basic tier. 
Cable system or cable television system or system means a system of antennas, cables, wires, lines, towers, waveguides, optical fiber, or other conductors, converters, equipment or facilities, designed and constructed for the purpose of producing, receiving, transmitting, amplifying and distributing audio, video, and other forms of electronic, electrical or optical signals, which the City legally can regulate and located in the City. The definition shall not include any such facility that serves or will serve only subscribers in one or more multiple unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management, and which does not use City rights-of-way. 
Channel means a portion of the electromagnetic frequency spectrum which is used in a cable system and which is capable of delivering a television channel as a television channel is defined by the Federal Communications Commission. 
City means the City of Palm Coast, Florida. 
Control and/or controlling interest shall mean actual working control of a system in whatever manner exercised. A change in the control or controlling interest of an entity which has control or a controlling interest in a franchisee shall constitute a change in the control or controlling interest of the System under the same criteria. Control or controlling interest as used herein may be held simultaneously by more than one person or entity. 
Converter means an electronic device which converts signals to a frequency not susceptible to interference within the television receiver of a subscriber, and by an appropriate channel selector also permits a subscriber to view more than 12 channels delivered by the system at designated converter dial locations. 
Drop shall mean the cable or wire that connects the distribution portion of a cable system to a subscriber's premises. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission and any legally appointed, designated or elected agent or successor. 
Franchise means the nonexclusive right granted through the authority of a franchise agreement between the City and a franchisee hereunder which allows the franchisee to own, operate, construct, reconstruct, upgrade, dismantle, test, use, and maintain a Cable System within the corporate boundaries of the City, and is not intended to include any license or permit required for the privilege of transacting and carrying on a business within the City as may be required by other laws or ordinances of the City. 
Franchise agreement means that certain written agreement entered into between a franchisee and the City wherein the franchise and the terms thereof are conferred upon the franchisee. 
Franchisee means a person or entity to whom or which a franchise under this chapter is granted by the City, along with the lawful successors or assigns of such person or entity. 
Gross revenues means all revenue received directly or indirectly by the franchisee, from the provision of cable services within the City, including, but not limited to, basic subscriber service monthly fees, pay cable fees, installation and reconnection fees, franchise fees, late fees and fees for cable modem service, ( in the event that cable modem service is classified as a cable service by a court of competent jurisdiction in a final ruling), leased channel fees, converter rentals, downgrade fees, advertising revenue less agency fees; provided, however, that this shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the franchisee herein imposed directly upon any subscriber or user by the state, local or other governmental unit and collected by the franchisee on behalf of the governmental unit, or the portion of the money received by the franchisee which is attainable to the franchise fee, as that term is used in applicable law. 
Service area means all areas in the City. 
Installation means the connection of the system from feeder cable to subscribers' terminals. 
May is permissive. 
Monitoring means observing a communications signal, or the absence of a signal, where the observer is neither the subscriber nor the programmer, whether the signal is observed by visual or electronic means, for any purpose whatsoever; provided monitoring shall not include system-wide, non-individually addressed sweeps of the system for purposes of verifying system integrity, controlling return paths transmissions, or billing for pay services. 
Normal business hours shall mean those hours during which most similar businesses in the community are open to serve customers, as defined by federal regulations. 
Normal operating conditions shall mean those service conditions which are within the control of the franchisee. Those conditions which are not within the control of the franchisee include, but are not limited to, natural disasters, civil disturbances, power outages, telephone network outages, and severe or unusual weather conditions. Those conditions which are ordinarily within the control of the franchisee include, but are not limited to, special promotions, rate increases, regular peak or seasonal demand periods, and maintenance or upgrade of a cable system. 
Educational, or governmental access facilities means channel capacity designated for educational or governmental use, and facilities and equipment for the use of such channel capacity. 
Service interruption means the loss of picture or sound on one or more channels. 
Shall is mandatory. 
Street means the surface of and all rights-of-way and the space above and below any public street, road, highway, freeway, lane, path, public way or place, sidewalk, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive or easement now or hereafter held by the City for the purpose of public travel and shall include other easements or rights-of-way as shall be now held or hereafter held by the City which shall, within their proper use and meaning, entitle the franchisee to the use thereof for the purposes of installing poles, wires, cable, conductors, ducts, conduits, vaults, manholes, amplifiers, appliances, attachments, optical fiber, and other property as may be ordinarily necessary and pertinent to a cable television system. 
Subscriber shall mean any person, firm, corporation, or association lawfully receiving basic and/or additional cable service from franchisee. 
User means a party utilizing a cable television system channel for purposes of production or transmission of material to subscribers, as contrasted with receipt thereof in a subscriber capacity. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 2, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-53. - Conflicting provisions. 
(a)  This article is adopted pursuant to the authority of the City under the Constitutions and Statutes of the State of Florida and the United States of America, including, but not limited to, the Cable Communication Policy Act of 1984, 47 U.S.C. 521, the Cable Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, the Telecommunications Act of 1996, and Florida Statutes 166.046 and 366.031. 
(b)  In the case of a conflict between a provision in this article and either a provision in a franchise agreement executed pursuant to this article or a provision in a franchise proposal that is incorporated by reference into such franchise agreement, this article shall control, unless the franchise agreement expresses an explicit intent to waive a requirement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 3, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-54. - Use of streets. 
(a)  Before any construction is commenced, the franchisee shall obtain all required and approved construction permits from the City and any other permits as may be required by law. Franchisee shall pay any and all inspection fees associated with obtaining such permits. The City shall have the right to inspect all construction or installation work performed by the franchisee in the City's streets. In the event of damage to property caused by franchisee, then franchisee must restore private property and public thoroughfares to their former conditions in a reasonable manner acceptable to the City or the private property owner as the case may be; if this is not done within 30 days, barring unforeseen circumstances, the City or private property owner may, after prior written notice to franchisee, cause reasonable repairs to be made at the expense of franchisee. 
(b)  The facilities shall be so located or relocated and so erected or installed so as not to obstruct or interfere with the use of streets, alleys, easements, and other public ways and places, or other utilities or structures already installed or hereinafter to be installed, subject at all times to the lawful police power of the City. Any unreasonable obstruction of any street, alley, avenue, bridge, easement or other public place or way of the City not promptly removed by the franchisee after written notice by the City demanding removal thereof, or not properly repaired by the franchisee after its work therein, after written notice by City demanding repair thereof, may be removed or repaired, as the case may be, by the City, and all reasonable costs thereof shall be charged against said franchisee and shall be collectible by the City in any lawful manner. 
(c)  Franchisee may trim trees on private property at the franchisee's expense, with prior approval of the property owner. Franchisee may trim trees on public rights-of-way at its own expense, but only after written notification to and the approval of the City. Approval will be deemed granted within three business days after written notification to the City if the City has not contacted the franchisee. In addition, removal of trees for new construction shall first require tree removal permits to be obtained by the franchisee at its expense. 
(d)  At the request of any person holding a valid building moving permit, the franchisee must temporarily raise, lower or cut its wires, as necessary to facilitate such move, upon not less than five business days advance notice. The direct expense of such temporary changes must be paid by the permit holder and the franchisee may require payment in advance. 
(e)  Franchisee must utilize existing poles, conduits, or other such facilities wherever possible, if available on reasonable terms and conditions. All transmission lines and structures must be installed to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners. Franchisee must obtain permission from the City before erecting any new poles or underground conduit at the time franchisee seeks to install any new lines. Approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(f)  On streets and roads where electrical and telephone utility wiring is installed underground, at the time of the initial cable construction, or if subsequently both go underground, cable must also be installed underground at no expense to the City, except to the extent the City bears the expenses of other parties similarly situated. If both electric and telephone utility wiring is aerial, franchisee may install aerial cable, except where a property owner or resident requests underground installation, and property owner or resident agrees to bear the additional cost over aerial construction. 
(g)  The City shall give franchisee reasonable notice of plans for street improvements when paving or resurfacing of a permanent nature is involved. Any relocation required by the City because of said improvements shall be at the expense of the franchisee. If all or part of a street within the City is closed or discontinued, franchisee shall not be entitled to damages from the City due to the closing or discontinuance of such street, because of removal or relocation of lines or cables by the franchisee in said streets. However, if funding becomes available to the City for undergrounding to reimburse users in the public rights of way, then cable franchisees will be reimbursed for their costs of relocation in the same manner as other users of the rights of way are reimbursed. 
(h)  All poles, lines, structures, and other facilities of franchisee, in, on, over and under the streets, sidewalks, alleys, easements and other public grounds or places within City shall be kept by franchisee at all times in a safe, sound and substantial condition. 
(i)  The franchisee's work, while in progress, shall be properly protected at all times with suitable barricades, flags, lights, flares, or other devices to protect all members of the public having occasion to use the portion of the streets involved or adjacent property. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 4, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-55. - Grant of authority; franchise required. 
(a)  The City may grant one or more franchises in accordance with this article. 
(b)  No person shall commence construction of a cable system on the public rights-of-way, or operate a cable system in the City, without receiving a franchise granted by the City and executing a franchise agreement with the City. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 5, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-56. - Franchise characteristics. 
(a)  A franchise authorizes use of the public rights-of-way for installing cables, wires, lines, optical fiber, and other facilities to operate a cable system within a specified area of the City, but does not expressly or implicitly authorize the franchisee to provide service to, or install cables, wires, lines, optical fiber, or any other equipment or facilities upon private property without owner consent (except for use of compatible easements pursuant to 47 U.S.C. § 541(a)(2) or as otherwise provided by law), or to use publicly or privately owned utility poles or conduits without a separate agreement with the owners. 
(b)  A franchise is nonexclusive, and will not expressly or implicitly preclude the issuance of other franchises to operate cable systems within the City or affect the City's right to authorize use of public rights-of-way to other persons as it determines appropriate. A franchise shall not be granted on terms or conditions more favorable or less burdensome than those in any existing franchise. 
(c)  Once a franchise agreement has been accepted and executed by the City and a franchisee, such franchise agreement shall constitute a contract between the franchisee and the City, and the terms, conditions and provisions of such franchise agreement, together with all duly enacted and applicable laws, ordinances, codes, rules, regulations and orders, shall define the rights and obligations of the franchisee and the City relating to the franchise, except as set forth in section 27-90(a). 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 6, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-57. - Franchise subject to other laws. 
(a)  A franchisee is subject to, and must comply with, all generally applicable local, City, State and Federal laws, ordinances, codes, rules, regulations, and orders. 
(b)  Except as may be specifically provided in this article or under the terms of a franchise agreement, the failure of the City, upon one or more occasions, to exercise a right, or to require compliance, or performance under the article or a franchise agreement shall not be deemed to constitute a waiver of such right or waiver of compliance or performance in the future. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 7, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-58. - Interpretation of franchise terms. 
(a)  Subject to provisions of section 27-90, the provisions of this article will apply to a franchise agreement, and the express terms of this article will prevail over conflicting or inconsistent provisions in a franchise agreement, unless such franchise agreement expresses an explicit intent to waive a requirement of the article. 
(b)  The provisions of a franchise agreement will be liberally construed to effectuate its purposes and objectives consistent with this article and the public interest. Except where federal law or regulation is controlling, a franchise agreement will be governed by and construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Florida. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 8, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-59. - Grant of franchises. 
(a)  Generally, the City may grant a franchise for a period not to exceed ten years, although a longer franchise term up to a 15 year term may be granted if the City Council finds it would better meet community needs and interests. 
(b)  The City may make the grant of a franchise conditioned upon the completion of construction within a prescribed time or upon the performance of other specific obligations, which are to be set forth in the franchise agreement, specifying that failure to timely comply with the condition will cause the franchisee to be in material breach of its franchise agreement, and become subject to penalties pursuant to this article and the franchise agreement. Violations listed in section 27-84 shall be considered material breaches of this article. 
(c)  In evaluating an application for a new franchise, the City shall consider among other things, the following factors: the applicant's character, its technical, financial, and legal qualifications to construct and operate the proposed system; the nature of the proposed facilities, equipment and services; the applicant's record in other communities, if any; the economic impact on private property within the proposed service area; the capability of the public rights-of-way to accommodate the proposed system; potential disruption to existing users of the public rights-of-way and the public; and whether the proposal will meet reasonably anticipated community needs and serve the public interest. Where an applicant proposes an overbuild of an existing cable system, the City shall also consider, pursuant to Florida Statutes Section 166.046, the economic feasibility of multiple cable operators, the impact on the existing franchisee, including whether the operations of an existing cable franchisee will be interfered with or disrupted, and whether any adverse consequences to the public interest will result if the application is granted. 
(d)  The Council shall hold a public hearing to consider any new application. Based upon the application, the testimony presented at the public hearing, any recommendations of the City Manager, and any other information it deems relevant to the application, the Council shall decide whether to grant or deny a franchise application and the terms and conditions of a grant. Any grant of a franchise shall be under terms and conditions that are not more favorable or less burdensome than those in an existing franchise. 
(e)  If the Council grants an initial franchise application, the City Manager and the applicant must agree on the terms of a franchise agreement within 90 calendar days from the date City Council approves the grant. This time period may be extended for good cause by the City. If agreement is not reached with the City within 90 calendar days or if the period is not extended by the City, the franchise grant will be null and void without further action by the City. 
(f)  After complying with the above requirements, the Council, following a public hearing, and considering the testimony presented at the public hearing, any recommendations of the City Manager, and any other relevant information, shall approve or disapprove the proposed franchise agreement by resolution. 
(g)  A franchisee must demonstrate compliance with the surety, insurance and similar provisions of the franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 9, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-60. - Complaints. 
(a)  Franchisee shall maintain and operate its system and render efficient service in accordance with the rules and regulations which are or which may be set forth by the City from time to time in the exercise of its authority under applicable law, and subject to section 27-90(a) of this article. 
(b)  Whenever it is necessary to shut off or interrupt service for the making of repairs, installations, or adjustments, franchisee shall do so at such times as will cause the least amount of inconvenience to its customers and unless such interruption is unforeseen and immediately necessary, it will give reasonable notice thereof to its customers. 
(c)  The franchisee shall maintain an office located convenient to the City which shall be open at reasonable hours for receiving complaints from subscribers and non-subscribers. Said complaints shall be investigated and if attributable to the system, corrected within the time frames set forth in section 27-73 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 10, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-61. - Rates. 
(a)  Before any service is sold to any customer, a franchisee shall file with the City Manager its schedule of rates for installation and monthly service charges and any other information required by the Federal rules. 
(b)  Subsequent additions or amendments to rates, service charges and rights and obligations statements shall likewise be filed with the City Manager at least 30 days before the same become effective. Simultaneously, a franchisee shall also provide subscribers to the cable system with written notification of any such additions or amendments at least 30 days before the same become effective. 
(c)  In the event that any state or federal law or regulation is at any time after the effective date of this article, enacted, changed, modified, interpreted, amended, repealed or invalidated so as to allow for the City's regulation of rates paid by cable subscribers, the City may, at its option, regulate such rates as permitted by law. 
(d)  Rate regulation proceedings shall be conducted at a duly noticed public hearing to ensure that all interested parties have a reasonable opportunity to present their views. The Council may conduct such hearings at its regularly scheduled meeting or at a meeting scheduled solely for the purpose of regulating rates. 
(e)  To the extent allowed by state and federal law, nothing in this section shall prevent a franchisee from applying a surcharge or late payment penalty to subscriber bills to reflect balances due the franchisee which are delinquent for 20 days or more. 
(Ord. No. 06-18, § 11, 10-17-06)  
Sec. 27-62. - Indemnification.
