Sec. 44-154. - Vehicle registration; classifications; requirements. 
(a)  Any vehicle for hire operated, caused to be operated, or driven with the intent to pick up passengers, originate one-way transportation, or provide return service for a round-trip transportation within the jurisdictional limits of or upon the public streets of the City shall be subject to the regulations, restrictions and conditions set forth in this article. 
(b)  The following categories of vehicles for hire shall be exempt from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Ambulances licensed by the State of Florida; 
(2)  Hearses, operated or limited exclusively to use by a licensed mortician; 
(3)  Passenger vehicles seating more than 20 persons that are not used for a transportation related commercial purpose; 
(4)  Passenger vehicles owned, operated, leased or controlled by a governmental agency; 
(5)  Shuttle services using a van owned and operated directly by a hotel or motel for transportation limited to registered guests thereof (it shall be presumed that this exemption is not applicable if the van does not bear any advertising or identification of the hotel or motel); 
(6)  Exclusive ride-sharing vehicles as defined in Section 341.031(9), Florida Statutes, as amended; 
(7)  School buses subject to the provisions of Chapters 234 and 316, Florida Statutes, as amended; 
(8)  Vehicle for hire services provided that the vehicles used to provide such services shall be clearly and distinctively marked as disadvantaged transportation; and provided, further, that any of the vehicles used to provide disadvantaged transportation shall be operated by a driver holding a driver permit providing for transportation services: 
a.  As outlined in Section 427.015(2), Florida Statutes, to the transportation disadvantaged, as defined in Section 427.011(1), Florida Statutes, as amended; or 
b.  By a transportation operator, as defined in Section 427.011(6), Florida Statutes, as amended; or 
c.  Pursuant to a contract authorized in Section 427.0155, Florida Statutes, as amended, with the Community Transportation Coordinator, as defined in Section 427.011(5), Florida Statutes which contract is on file with the vehicle for hire administrator; 
(9)  Transportation services operated: 
a.  As a bona-fide tour company by a seller of travel as defined in Section 559.927, Florida Statutes, as amended, or 
b.  Operated by a person who, as determined in writing by the vehicle for hire administrator, provides the vehicle for hire service to the passengers as an ancillary part of a primary scheduled service or tour. 
(10)  The single motor vehicle independent contractor who operates without connection with any other driver, association of drivers, or any entity, of whatsoever type or nature, providing transportation services in the nature of a vehicle for hire. However, such operators shall be registered with the City and pay the established registration fee. 
(c)  Every vehicle for hire permitted pursuant to this article shall be classified according to one of the following categories: 
(1)  Taxicab; 
(2)  Limousine; or 
(3)  Shuttle service. 
(d)  The applicant for a permit shall request the particular category on the application for a vehicle permit submitted. The classification shall be made by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(e)  The purposes of the classifications are to: 
(1)  Ensure that different forms of vehicle for hire service are recognized; 
(2)  Avoid misleading information or creating confusion among the traveling public; and 
(3)  Provide notice to the permit holder of the classification and the applicable limitations and regulations pertaining to the category. 
(f)  Vehicle for hire permit holders shall only provide the services specified below: 
(1)  A permit holder in the taxicab classification may only: 
a.  Provide general transportation of persons not on regular schedules with the routes traveled or the destination determined by the passengers; 
b.  Provide good and reasonable service at all times to all parts of the City 24 hours a day, each and every day of the year, unless prevented by a labor strike or an act of God; 
c.  Maintain a business office with sufficient employees to answer all calls 24 hours a day, each and every day of the year; 
d.  Base the fare charged to the passenger on the use of the vehicle without regard to the number of passengers carried; 
e.  Determine the fare by a meter; and 
f.  Provide the taxicab service in an automobile, station wagon or van that is capable of comfortably seating at least four adult passengers, and the driver and a maximum of nine adult passengers. 
(2)  A permit holder in the limousine classification may provide the transportation of persons as follows: 
a.  Limited to a limousine luxury sedan or luxury van; 
b.  Leased, rented or charged upon for a minimum time period of one hour (60 minutes); 
c.  With the fare determined on an hourly basis and not by a meter or mileage for the use of the vehicle; and 
d.  Pre-arranged or arranged through a third party (e.g., guest service desk or concierge desk). 
(3)  A permit holder in the shuttle service classification may provide the transportation of persons as follows: 
a.  Limited to a van; 
b.  On a scheduled service; 
c.  With the fare determined on a per capita basis and not by a meter or mileage; and 
d.  Pre-arranged or arranged through a third party (e.g., guest service desk or concierge desk). 
(g)  Each permit holder shall strictly comply with the regulations and requirements for the particular category of a vehicle for hire as outlined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 4, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-155. - Permit application and permit procedure for vehicle-for-hire services. 
(a)  An application for a permit shall be filed with the vehicle for hire administrator with an application fee established by resolution of the City Council. The application fee shall not apply to renewal or additional permit applications which shall be subject to additional fees. 
(b)  The application shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  The name of the applicant; 
(2)  The name of the applicant's business and trade name under which the business will operate and a copy of proof of payment or occupational license taxes; 
(3)  If the business is a partnership, whether general or limited, the partnership instrument or certified copy thereof, and the business address of the partnership; 
(4)  If the business is a corporation, the certificate of incorporation or certified copies thereof, and the business address of the corporation; 
(5)  If the business is to be conducted under another name than that of the applicant, a copy of the fictitious name certificate, if required; 
(6)  The applicant's business location; 
(7)  The applicant's business mailing address; 
(8)  The applicant's business phone number; 
(9)  The applicant's home address and home phone number; 
(10)  The category of permit requested; 
(11)  The seating capacity, make, model, year of manufacture, mileage, equipment and amenities for each vehicle to be used; 
(12)  The color scheme of the vehicles the applicant intends to operate; 
(13)  The type and make of radios or communication devices the applicant will be using in the vehicles; 
(14)  The names and addresses of any and all persons holding a ten percent or greater beneficial interest in the applicant's business or company; 
(15)  The date the application is filed with the vehicle for hire administrator; 
(16)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of at least three references from persons not related to the applicant who have knowledge of the applicant; 
(17)  A proposal for submission of appropriate insurance coverage or proof of coverage; 
(18)  If applicable, a proposed agreement with telephone directory(ies) that is distributed within the entire corporate limits of the City, indicating required advertising and the telephone number which will be used by customers to contact the business for service; 
(19)  A factual statement and documentation indicating the portion(s) of the vehicle for hire market to be served and such other pertinent information as the applicant may desire to present; 
(20)  Any other information required, as deemed appropriate by the vehicle for hire administrator, of any applicant for the particular classification of vehicle for hire service. The additional requirements shall be consistent with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Within three business days after receipt of an application and payment of the application fee, the vehicle for hire administrator shall review the application to ensure that the application is complete and all information required has been provided. The vehicle for hire administrator shall, with the completeness review, categorize the vehicle for hire service in the appropriate classification. Permits shall be issued or denied within 15 days after the date of completeness determination. Failure to disclose any person holding an interest in the proposed permit shall be grounds for the rejection of the application. 
(d)  In making a determination as to whether the permit will be issued to the applicant, the vehicle for hire administrator shall consider the following criteria: 
(1)  Completeness of the application as required by this article; 
(2)  Completeness of the application support documentation as required by this article; 
(3)  Whether the color scheme, logo, trade name and exterior design are sufficiently unique from any other permit holder as to prevent confusion for the riding public and infringement of an existing permit holder's color scheme, logo, trade name and exterior design; 
(4)  Verification of references; and 
(5)  The applicant's experience in operating a vehicle for hire or in operating a vehicle for hire business. 
(e)  In addition to other requirements set forth in this article, the following criteria shall apply for the issuance of additional permits to an existing permit holder: 
(1)  Adherence of the permit holder, and its drivers, to the provisions of this article, other applicable ordinances of the City and of the Code of the City of Palm Coast; 
(2)  Whether or not the requirements for issuance of any initial permit as described in this article continue to be met; 
(3)  Any evidence received from citizen complaints or the City as to the quality of service provided by the permit holder and its drivers and compliance with the provisions of this article; 
(4)  Trip reports and business records of the permit holder and its drivers; and 
(5)  Any other relevant or pertinent information from either the general public or the City. 
(f)  If after review of the application, the vehicle for hire administrator finds that the applicant does not meet the application requirements, the vehicle for hire administrator shall deny the application. The denial may be: 
(1)  Conditional and affording the applicant an opportunity to provide further information or take other action which may result in approval of the applicant by the vehicle for hire administrator; or 
(2)  Final. 
(g)  Upon a determination that a permit shall be issued, the vehicle for hire administrator shall issue the permit upon submission of the following documents: 
(1)  Insurance certification proving that the applicant has met the insurance requirements; 
(2)  Vehicle inspection certification from an inspection facility, as designated by the City Council, certifying that the vehicle(s) to be permitted meet(s) the safety and equipment, a requirement of this article; provided, however, any person or company holding permits for 25 vehicles or more and operating a facility for maintaining and repairing said vehicles and such inspections are performed by A.S.E. (Automotive Service Excellence) certified mechanics, may conduct the safety inspections of those vehicles as required by this article. All permit holders qualifying as self inspectors must be in compliance with the A.S.E. requirements. Said certification shall have been issued not more than 30 days prior to the issuance of the permit. This requirement may be waived for any vehicle with a manufacture date that is less than 365 days from the date such permit is to be issued and which has less than 10,000 miles in mileage. The vehicle for hire administrator or designee shall conduct, at no cost, an inspection of such vehicle to determine compliance with requirements such as a "Doing Business As" tag and two-way communication device; 
(3)  If required, a receipt or certified copy from applicable telephone carrier(s) for advertisement in the upcoming yellow pages; 
(4)  Submission of every vehicle identification number, state license plate number, mileage and the original or copy of the State of Florida registration; and 
(5)  Proof of payment of occupational license taxes. 
(h)  Prior to issuance of the vehicle permit(s) by the vehicle for hire administrator, the applicant shall pay a permit fee for each permit established by resolution of the City Council. 
(i)  Permits shall be valid for one year until the last day of the month in which the permit was issued the year prior. 
(j)  Permits shall be issued for the classification approved by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(k)  The permit decal for the permit shall be affixed to each vehicle for hire in a manner determined by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(l)  Each permit holder shall maintain in active operation each vehicle for which the permit was issued. Any permit which remains dormant for more than 90 consecutive days or 150 days in any calendar year may be revoked and declared void by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(m)  A permit issued, renewed, awarded or transferred herein shall not vest the permit holder with any property rights in said permit. 
(n)  Sixty days prior to the expiration of a permit, the permit holder may renew the permit for an additional 12-month term by submitting an application for renewal to the vehicle for hire administrator. The renewal application shall contain the same information as the original application. The vehicle for hire administrator shall review each application and, within ten days of the receipt of a completed application, either approve or deny the application. Upon approval of the renewal permit, the renewal permit shall be issued upon the payment of a fee established by resolution of the City Council. Permit holders who renew a permit after the expiration date shall be assessed a late fee established by resolution of the City Council. Permit renewals after 30 days shall be processed as an additional permit request. A late renewal of permit shall be presumptive evidence of operating without a permit. 
(o)  If a decal for the permit is lost or destroyed or a replacement decal is requested, the permit holder may obtain a duplicate decal upon the payment of a service charge established by resolution of the City Council. It is prohibited and unlawful for any person to place, or cause another to place, a permit decal on any vehicle other than that vehicle to which the permit decal was assigned. 
(p)  The transfer from one permit holder to another shall not be effective until the transfer permit has been issued by the vehicle for hire administrator. The transfer of a permit to a person who is not a current permit holder licensed herein, shall not be effective until the proposed transferee/assignee submits an application, pays the application fees, and obtains approval. 
(q)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a permit holder to sell, bargain, grant, demise, lease, option or assign (hereinafter collectively "transfer") a permit except as provided for in this article. Any attempted transfer of any permit, not provided for in this article shall result in an automatic revocation of the permit. 
(r)  Any permit holder may lease or contract for dispatch and vehicle maintenance services with another permit holder. A permit holder leasing dispatch or vehicle maintenance services from another permit holder must operate under the color scheme of the permit holder that is providing the leased services. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 5, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-156. - Driver permits. 
(a)  Any person who operates or drives a vehicle for hire within the City of or upon any street in the City shall first obtain a driver permit, as set forth in this article. 
(b)  Any person being 18 years of age or older may make application to the City for a driver permit. The application shall include, at a minimum, the following items: 
(1)  Applicant's name, date of birth, social security number, sex, race or national origin, and any aliases or former legal names used during the preceding five-year period; 
(2)  Applicant's home address and mailing address as well as e-mail addresses; 
(3)  Applicant's home phone number, cellular telephone number and existing work phone number; 
(4)  Proof that the applicant holds a valid Florida driver's license; 
(5)  The names, addresses, and phone numbers of the applicant's existing employer, and any other employer during the preceding three years; 
(6)  The addresses of each and every place of residence or domicile of the applicant during the preceding three years; 
(7)  Two photographs of the applicant of the size and type as determined by the City; 
(8)  A sworn affidavit by the applicant which states that the applicant has not been convicted of within the past five years, or he/she does not have any charges pending against him/her for any of the following crimes: 
a.  Driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol, 
b.  Vehicular manslaughter, 
c.  Reckless driving, 
d.  Murder, manslaughter, armed robbery, assault with a deadly weapon, or aggravated assault, 
e.  Any crime which is designated as a felony, 
f.  Any crime involving the sale or possession of a controlled substances as defined by Section 893.03, Florida Statutes, 
g.  The Florida RICO Act, 
h.  Exposure of the sexual organs and any crime defined under Chapter 800, Florida Statutes, or 
i.  Any crime defined as Prostitution under Chapter 796, Florida Statutes, including, but not limited to, assignation or solicitation for prostitution. 
(9)  The name, address and phone number of the permit holder for vehicle for hire services for which the applicant is working or intends to work; 
(10)  Such other information as the City may require of all applicants, including but not limited to, a Florida Department of Law Enforcement inquiry; 
(11)  Payment of an application fee, established by resolution of the City Council. 
(c)  Upon receipt of an application and evidence of the payment of the application fee, the vehicle for hire administrator shall review the application to ensure that the application is complete and all information requested has been provided. The vehicle for hire administrator shall determine whether the applicant understands and is reasonably conversant in the English language for the demands of a driver and the requirements of this article. 
(d)  If the application is deemed complete by the vehicle for hire administrator and the applicant successfully shows that he/she is reasonably conversant in the English language, then the application and the affidavits shall be verified for accuracy by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(e)  A driver's permit shall not be issued if within the last five years immediately preceding the application, the applicant has been convicted of, or has pending charges for, any of the following: 
(1)  Driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol, 
(2)  Vehicular manslaughter, 
(3)  Reckless driving, 
(4)  Murder, manslaughter, armed robbery, assault with a deadly weapon, or aggravated assault, 
(5)  Any crime which is designated as a felony, 
(6)  Any crime involving the sale or possession of controlled substances as defined by Section 893.03, Florida Statutes, 
(7)  The Florida RICO Act, 
(8)  Exposure of the sexual organs and any crime defined under Chapter 800, Florida Statutes, or 
(9)  Any crime defined as Prostitution under Chapter 796, Florida Statutes, including, but not limited to, assignation or solicitation for prostitution. 
(f)  The applicant shall have the burden of proof to show by substantial competent evidence that the applicant has been reformed, rehabilitated, and without any reasonable doubt, does not pose a safety risk to members of the traveling public. Substantial competent evidence shall not include testimony of the applicant without verification by independent sources such as employment records, parole records, evidence of completion of drug and/or alcohol rehabilitation and testimony of third parties. Ten days prior to the hearing, the applicant shall provide a list of the evidence and witnesses to the vehicle for hire administrator. Failure to list the evidence or witnesses shall bar the submission of the unlisted evidence or witnesses to the City. 
(g)  If after review of the application, the vehicle for hire administrator finds that the applicant does not meet the application requirements, the vehicle for hire administrator shall deny the application. The denial may be: 
(1)  Conditional and affording the applicant an opportunity to provide further information or take other action which may result in approval of the applicant by the vehicle for hire administrator; or 
(2)  Final. 
(h)  Each driver permit issued shall bear the driver's name, photograph, permit number, and expiration date. The City shall maintain a photograph of the driver on file. 
(i)  Every driver shall have his/her permit visibly displayed on the exterior of the driver's blouse or shirt or in any vehicle operated at all times when on duty, and shall produce it upon demand of any passenger, City code enforcement officer or administrator or City, County, or State Law Enforcement Officer. 
(j)  Driver permits shall be valid for a period of three years from the date of issuance. 
(k)  If any of the information supplied by the driver in the application is no longer accurate, the driver shall then provide current and accurate information to City within 30 days of the date the change occurs. The information filed with the vehicle for hire administrator, or designee, shall be assumed correct and exclusively relied upon as the correct address for all notices and enforcement proceedings herein. Failure to maintain the accuracy of the application information on file shall result in automatic suspension of said permit. Unless otherwise prohibited by this article, the City Code or any other applicable law, rule or regulation, no driver shall refuse any request for transportation from any orderly passenger where the destination of the trip is within the Flagler County area. Any driver may request or demand advance payment prior to commencement of a trip, and refuse to initiate such trip and may terminate a trip and/or may request payment if the driver has reason to believe the passenger(s) may cause bodily injury to him/her, or the passenger(s) become unruly, rowdy or cause physical damage to the vehicle or the driver. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 6, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-157. - Safety and equipment standards. 
(a)  Every vehicle for hire shall meet the following minimum safety and equipment standards: 
(1)  Tires shall be of the size appropriate for the vehicle for hire and with no mismatched tires. There shall be no cuts into the tire cord or sidewall area or localized worn spots that expose the ply. No tire is permitted with less than two-thirty second ( 2/32 ) inches remaining when measured in any two grooves at three equally spaced intervals around the circumference of the tire, or when the tire has tread wear indicators that are visible. 
(2)  The vehicle for hire shall be equipped with an operational horn with the actuating button mounted in the location designated by the vehicle manufacturer and operated in the manner designed and assembled by the vehicle manufacturer. 
(3)  The windshield, side and rear windows shall operate as designed and be assembled with no breakage, cracks or pits that may impair visibility or hinder the safety of passengers. It is prohibited and unlawful for any windows on a vehicle for hire to be composed of, covered by, or treated with, any material which would cause the vehicle to be in violation of Section 316.295, Florida Statutes. 
(4)  All doors must have operating handles that allow opening from the inside and outside. Handles, knobs and armrests shall be free of breaks and must be securely mounted. Door hinges and hold stops shall function correctly. Door seals and gaskets shall be intact and operating to seal water and odors from entering the passenger compartment from outside. All door panels shall be intact to prevent accidental injuries on door and window mechanisms. 
(5)  The interior condition of each vehicle for hire shall comply with the following: 
a.  All standard interior equipment shall be complete and intact including, but not limited to, interior lights, headliner, dashboard, head rests, window cranks and gear shifts. 
b.  Seat covers shall be permanently attached or fixed to all seats in the vehicle for hire, and shall have no exposed wire or sharp edges either from metal or hardened vinyl. The rear seat shall be of a type, size and mounting approved by the vehicle manufacturer. Broken springs, sagging or horizontal slippage in any seat are prohibited and unlawful. 
c.  Floor covering material shall be secure and contain no rips or loose folds. The floor board of the vehicle for hire shall be free of rust and holes. 
d.  Loose or moving objects or externally mounted speakers shall not be placed on the deck behind the rear seat, or on the front dash board. Decorations or other objects hanging from permanently mounted fixtures in a vehicle for hire. 
(6)  Each vehicle for hire shall have seat belts available for passengers in all seats except jump seats, spaces designed to accommodate wheelchairs or where the seat belts are not required by law. Seat belts shall be provided in good and effectual operating condition and easily accessible by all passengers. Seat belts shall be clean and free of grease and other objectionable substances. Seat belts which are placed under the seat or between the lower and upper portions of the seat are hereby conclusively deemed not easily accessible. 
(7)  Each vehicle for hire shall have standard operational windshield wipers for the entire front windshield which shall be controlled electronically or by vacuum and operated from the interior of the vehicle for hire. The wiper blades shall be in such a condition as to make firm contact with the windshield when operational and shall not be torn or badly worn. 
(8)  Each vehicle for hire shall contain an operational parking brake and a primary brake system which acts effectively on all four vehicle wheels. There shall be no visible leaks in the brake line, wheel cylinder or any part of the brake system and no frayed cables. All primary brake systems shall demonstrate a reasonable and safe total braking force when tested, using the "quick stop method" and with the vehicle for hire operating at a speed of at least 20 miles per hour. Brake linings and disc pads, when measured at the thinnest point, shall not be less than one-sixteenth of an inch. Brake linings and/or pads shall be firmly attached to the brake shoe and/or disk coupler. Disc brake rotors and brake drums shall be of a size and type appropriate for the vehicle, with no cracks or other damage which change or impair the functional surface. 
(9)  Every vehicle for hire shall be equipped with operational State of Florida-approved headlights, and turn indicating lamps or devices on the front and rear of the vehicle and a foot brake activated stop light on the rear of the vehicle. Each vehicle for hire shall have a tail lamp so situated on the vehicle as to illuminate the rear license plate with a white light and render it clearly legible. 
(10)  Steering mechanisms shall neither be worn or jammed, nor shall there be more than two inches play to the left or right of center, measured at the steering wheel rim with the road wheels in a straight ahead position, on wheels up to 18 inches in diameter, or three inches of play on wheels over 18 inches. 
(11)  There shall be no leakage of exhaust gas at the manifold gasket, manifold and exhaust line gasket, muffler and muffler connections or at any other point in the exhaust system as determined through a visual and audible inspection. The tail pipe shall discharge exhaust from the rear or sides of the passenger and luggage compartment. It is prohibited and unlawful for any part of the exhaust system to pass through or leak into the part of the vehicle for hire occupied by passengers, as determined by visual inspection. 
(12)  Every vehicle for hire shall be equipped with an adequately operating air conditioning and heating system, and windshield defrost or defogging system, which controls the temperature of the interior of the vehicle between 68°F to 78°F. 
(13)  Every vehicle for hire permit holder shall repair or replace any equipment or parts of the vehicle found to be worn out, defective or creating a safety hazard by the vehicle inspection facility as a result of the inspection. 
(14)  Every taxicab shall be equipped with a "taxicab meter" or "meter" for registering the fare to be charged. Each taxicab meter shall be inspected, approved and sealed pursuant to Chapter 531, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 7, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-158. - Meters. 
(a)  Every meter in use shall be placed in the taxicab at a location that will be plainly visible at all times to the passengers of the taxicab. Between the hours of sunset and sunrise, the dial of the meter shall be illuminated whenever the ignition of the vehicle is on. 
(b)  Whenever a taxicab is not hired, the meter shall show no fare. When a taxicab is hired, the meter shall be in the calculating position. Upon the completion of service by a taxicab, the meter shall be returned to the non-calculating position and its dial cleared. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the taxicab permit holder to have the meter in good working condition and operating accurately as to the registration of mileage and fare. Meters shall be sealed in a manner that will prevent any person from tampering with or changing the adjustment of the meter. 
(d)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any category of vehicle for hire, except a taxicab, to be equipped, have installed, or possess within its interior a taxicab meter, whether or not the meter is in operation. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 8, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-159. - Communication devices. 
(a)  All vehicles for hire shall be equipped with either cellular telephones or reliable and accessible communications systems such that office dispatchers may immediately and effectively notify drivers of requests for service in order that drivers may immediately and effectively request assistance should assistance be needed. 
(b)  Any electrical device such as radar detectors/"fuzz busters", police two-way or similar scanners, or two-way radio frequency monitors are prohibited and unlawful to be located within a vehicle for hire or in the possession of a driver. Hand-carried AM-FM radios, televisions or other similar entertainment musical devices are allowed. 
(c)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a permit holder to possess at its place of business, dispatch operation or in any building or vehicle for hire any device used for the monitoring of a competitor's radio frequency. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 9, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-160. - Liability insurance or surety bond. 
(a)  Each permit holder shall possess a liability and property damage insurance policy issued by an insurance company or surety company who is authorized to do business in the State of Florida, or who has a current license under Federal law as a risk retention group for purposes of insurance. 
(b)  The coverage for each vehicle equipped to carry six or fewer passengers, including the driver, shall be maintained, at a minimum, in the following amounts: 
(1)  One hundred thousand dollars for injuries per person in any one occurrence or accident and $300,000.00 per occurrence or accident; and 
(2)  An amount of not less than $50,000.00 for property damage in any one accident. 
(c)  The coverage for each vehicle equipped to carry seven or more passengers, including the driver, shall be issued in the amount of $1,000,000.00 combined, single incident, or its equivalent. Any separate policy acquired in order to achieve the higher level of coverage must have the same expiration date as the main policy. 
(d)  Each insurance policy shall list the City as an additional insured with all notices of any kind (including, but not limited to, termination, cancellation, reduction in coverage, renewal, or non-renewal) sent to the City at the address of the vehicle for hire administrator. The insurance policy shall contain, at a minimum, a 30 day written notice period prior to the effective date of termination, cancellation, reduction of coverage, renewal or non-renewal. 
(e)  All vehicle permits issued to a vehicle permit holder shall be covered under one master policy held by that permit holder. 
(f)  A permit holder may self-insure for the insurance requirements if: 
(1)  The permit holder is certified for financial responsibility as a self-insurer, and is current in standing with the insurance licensing offices of the State of Florida; 
(2)  The retention of exposure by the vehicle permit holder is no greater than allowed by the controlling provisions of the Florida Statutes; and 
(3)  The excess policies, at a minimum, satisfy the policy limits listed in paragraph (1), above. 
(g)  No policy of required insurance shall be canceled until the expiration of 30 days after notice of intended cancellation thereof has been given in writing to the vehicle for hire administrator by mail or personal delivery of such notice. 
(h)  Should a vehicle for hire at any time cease to be covered by a policy of insurance as required by this article, the vehicle permit shall be automatically suspended without the need for any action of the City and may only be reinstated in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 10, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-161. - Trade name and color scheme. 
(a)  Every permit holder shall operate under a trade name which is distinctive from and not substantially similar to any existing business, company or service operated or provided by a permit holder. All trade names are subject to approval by the vehicle for hire administrator as a condition to the issuance of the permit. Non-taxicab permit holders may contract with each other or other dispatch services under a collective trade name, provided the permit holder informs the vehicle for hire administrator in writing of the use of the collective trade name. 
(b)  Every taxicab permit holder shall: 
(1)  Display a uniform and distinct color scheme on all vehicles. All color schemes shall be subject to approval by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(2)  Have conspicuously and permanently affixed on such vehicle, on each side of the vehicle and in letters not less than four inches in height; 
(3)  Be painted with the uniform color scheme; 
(4)  Conspicuously and permanently display a company vehicle number on the front and rear bumpers and on each side of the outside of the vehicle in figures two to three inches in height and in the color approved by the vehicle for hire administrator; and 
(5)  Be equipped with a permanently installed roof mounted device commonly known as a top light which shall be illuminated whenever the meter is on, or when headlights and/or parking lights are illuminated. 
(c)  Every shuttle permit holder shall: 
(1)  Have conspicuously and permanently affixed on each vehicle, on each side of the vehicle and in letters not less than six inches in height, the trade name approved; 
(2)  Conspicuously and permanently display a company vehicle number on the front and rear bumpers and on both sides of the outside of the vehicle in figures two to three inches in height and in a color approved by the vehicle for hire administrator; 
(3)  Not place any type or form of light device or other device on the roof, commonly known as a top light or top hat, whether or not permanently or temporarily affixed to the vehicle; 
(4)  Not have any light device within the possession of the interior of the vehicle, except for the area exclusively limited to the storage of baggage behind the rearmost seat; and 
(5)  Not have the words or a sign with the words "taxicab," "taxi," "cab," "limousine," "limo," "luxury sedan" or "luxury" or form thereof, placed or affixed permanently or temporarily on any portion of the outside vehicle, or anywhere within the interior of the vehicle, except in the area exclusively limited to the storage of baggage behind the rearmost seat. 
(d)  Every limousine permit holder shall: 
(1)  Display the trade name or the approved collective trade name on the front license plate of the vehicle and the approved City vehicle number shall be on the front and rear bumpers of the vehicle in figures two to three inches in height and in the color approved by the vehicle for hire administrator; 
(2)  Not be painted the uniform color or design scheme of any permitted taxicab vehicle for hire; 
(3)  Not have the words or a sign with the words "taxicab," "taxi," "cab," "shuttle," or "shuttle service" or any form or translation thereof, placed or affixed permanently or temporarily on any window or portion of the outside vehicle, or anywhere within the interior of the vehicle excluding the trunk. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 11, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-162. - Advertisement regulations. 
(a)  Every taxicab permit holder shall obtain, at first opportunity, and thereafter continue to maintain for the duration of the taxicab permit, a listing in the taxicab section of the yellow pages of each telephone book distributed to a substantial majority of the residents and businesses within the City. The listing shall include the trade name approved for the taxicab permit holder and phone number(s) where the public can reach the taxicab permit holder's dispatch in order to obtain taxicab service. 
(b)  A non-taxicab permit holder may advertise, but is not required to do so. 
(c)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a taxicab permit holder to advertise, or allow or cause to be advertised, in any telephone directory, newspaper, brochure, bulletin, flyer, radio or television commercial, or hotel leaflet, an advertisement or solicitation for business which includes the word(s) "shuttle service," "limousine," "limo," or "shuttle" or "custom/luxury van," "van" or any form of these words. 
(d)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a limousine vehicle permit holder to advertise, or allow or cause to be advertised, in any telephone directory, newspaper, brochure, bulletin, flyer, radio or television commercial, or hotel leaflet, an advertisement or solicitation for business which includes the word(s) "shuttle service," "taxicab," "taxi," "cab," "luxury sedan," "shuttle" or "custom/luxury van," or any form of these words. 
(e)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a shuttle service permit holder to advertise, or allow or cause to be advertised, in any telephone directory, newspaper, brochure, bulletin, flyer, radio or television commercial, or hotel leaflet, an advertisement or solicitation for business which includes the word(s) "taxicab," "taxi," "cab," "limousine," "limo," "luxury sedan," or any form of these words. 
(f)  A permit holder, who has been issued permits for multiple categories, may use in one advertisement the terms for each particular category of permit issued to the permit holder. 
(g)  If the permit holder operates outside the City limits a category of vehicle for hire service for which no permit has been issued by the City, then the permit holder shall segregate the advertisement of the services into two separate advertisements: one for City service and one for non-City service. In the non-City advertisement, the vehicle permit holder shall not use, or allow the use of, the word "Palm Coast" in the advertisement for the vehicle for hire service operated outside the City. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 12, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-163. - Driver standards. 
(a)  Every permit holder shall require and ensure that every driver under its control or using its vehicles: 
(1)  Is hygienically clean, with his/her body well-groomed, neat, odor free, and clean in appearance, and the clothing clean and odor free; 
(2)  If a beard or mustache is worn, ensure that it is well-groomed and neatly trimmed at all times; 
(3)  Wear trousers or females may wear skirts or dresses providing that the hem is not more than two inches above the top of the knee joint and is not strapless or halter type, a shirt with a collar and sleeves, shoes and socks and appropriate outer garments, and shall not wear T-shirts, underwear worn as outer garments, tank tops, body shirts, swim wear, jogging or bathing shorts, sweat suits, work out clothing, trunks or suits, or similar types of attire, or outer garments or footwear that is frayed, ragged, holed or open, except that females may wear open toe footwear providing that such footwear is high-heeled and is not clogs, thongs, shower shoes or sandals. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 13, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-164. - Vehicles for hire rates and fares. 
(a)  All rates and surcharges imposed herein shall be adopted by resolution of the City Council. A meeting for the purpose of adopting the resolution shall be advertised ten days in advance in the local newspaper and the existing and proposed rates and/or surcharges shall be published in the advertisement. In the resolution, the City Council shall set an effective date for the new rates and/or surcharges. 
(b)  In establishing any rate or surcharge, the City Council shall be guided by the following criteria: 
(1)  The rates or surcharges established by other governments and in other similarly situated metropolitan areas across the nation; 
(2)  The Consumer Price Index for the transportation expenses for the past year; 
(3)  Historical data relating to the revenue generated by vehicle permit holder(s) in the City; 
(4)  Information provided by the American Automobile Association, or other similar local, regional or national transportation information source; 
(5)  The expenses and income of vehicle permit holders; and 
(6)  The expenses and income of drivers, if available. 
(c)  The vehicle for hire administrator shall have the right to examine all books and records of all permit holders and drivers. 
(d)  Any such rate or surcharge imposed, required or collected by any permit holder or driver shall be in strict conformance with the adopted rates and/or surcharges. 
(e)  The rates and/or any surcharges adopted by the City Council shall be posted by the vehicle for hire administrator and provided to each permit holder. 
(f)  Printed schedules of the current applicable rates, and/or surcharges shall be available at all times for inspection in all vehicles for hire. Within each taxicab, the schedule of the current adopted rates and/or surcharges adopted by City Council shall be permanently posted in a place with a view to the general public within the interior and on each door-side of the outside of the taxicab. In addition, if the City Council adopts any rate or surcharge charge for the particular category of vehicle for hire, then the vehicle permit holder shall post a sign or decal at least two inches by three inches at a location, to be determined and approved by the vehicle for hire administrator, in the interior, exterior or window of the vehicle, which states: 
(g)  It shall be the duty of the vehicle for hire permit holder to post the following signs within the interior of every vehicle for hire: 
(1)  A comment/complaint sign on the lower left corner of the right rear door window which states: If any comments or complaints, call the City of Palm Coast at (386) 986-3700. The City permit number of shall be at least two by three inches and approved by the vehicle for hire administrator; and 
(2)  The rate and/or surcharge sign. 
(h)  Every permit holder shall place on file with the vehicle for hire administrator the most current rates for its vehicle for hire service. 
(i)  Any rate or surcharge imposed, required or collected by any permit holder or driver shall be in conformance to the rate or surcharge established by the City Council. 
(j)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to charge or attempt to charge any passenger a greater rate of fare than that which is currently allowed. 
(k)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to accept or receive any money or other gratuity including money commonly referred to as turkey money from any hotel, motel, restaurant, or other business in consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger from a business establishment to another business establishment. 
(l)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a taxicab driver to operate a taxicab unless a taximeter is used to determine the fare to be charged. The taximeter must be a meter approved by the City to be used in the specific taxicab in which it is being used. It is prohibited and unlawful to operate a taxicab with a taximeter that has not been approved by the City for that specific taxicab. It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to operate a taxicab in which the driver knows the taximeter in the taxicab is not accurate. 
(m)  For a destination that is outside the City limits, the driver shall provide each passenger with a flat rate prior to transport. The rate must be agreed upon between the driver and the passenger before the trip begins. The agreement may include, with regard to taxicabs, running the taximeter the entire trip, as opposed to a flat rate. The taximeter must be in activation while inside the City limits, in the event the passenger(s) decides to terminate the trip before leaving the City. 
(n)  A driver may refuse any trip to a destination outside the City limits. Permit holders are encouraged to establish uniform rates to area airports and cities to make these rates available to their dispatchers. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 14, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-165. - Trip reports/records. 
(a)  The permit holder shall require that every driver will keep a trip report which shall show the following minimum information for each trip: 
(1)  The name of permit holder; 
(2)  The company unit number of the vehicle; 
(3)  The name of the driver; 
(4)  The date and time of trip origin; 
(5)  The origin and destination of the trip; 
(6)  The fare charged or the voucher number for the trip; and 
(7)  The number of passengers transported on the trip. 
(b)  Each trip report shall be consecutively numbered and shall be recorded on a form approved by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(c)  Each driver shall, on a daily basis, submit said trip reports to the permit holder who shall keep them for a period of at least 90 days. The trip reports shall be submitted daily, except drivers who lease the vehicle from the permit holder for a period longer than one day may submit the trip reports at the end of the lease period or weekly, whichever is shorter. 
(d)  All trip reports shall be at all times open to inspection by the vehicle for hire administrator or inspector(s) and shall be produced on demand. The trip reports shall be kept at the business office of the permit holder. 
(e)  If the permit holder uses dispatcher(s), the permit holder shall make a record of each call received, the time it is received, the point of origin, the time the request for service is dispatched, the time of pick-up and the destination, if indicated by the prospective passenger. Such record shall be kept in the dispatch office for a minimum period of 90 days. 
(f)  Each taxicab permit holder shall maintain records detailing the following information for a period of no less than two years: 
(1)  The total number of taxicab trips originating from an airport; 
(2)  The total number of taxicab service requests dispatched; 
(3)  The total number of taxicab trips made by all taxicabs excluding those taxicab trips originating at an airport; 
(4)  The total number of pick-ups that are over 20 minutes from the time dispatched; 
(5)  The total revenues generated for all taxicab metered miles for all taxicabs excluding those metered miles that originated from an airport; 
(6)  The total revenues generated for all taxicab metered miles for all City-permitted taxicabs originating from an airport; and 
(7)  The total taxicab metered miles driven for all taxicabs excluding those originating at an airport; and 
(8)  The total taxicab metered miles driven for all taxicabs originating from an airport; and 
(9)  The total vehicle miles driven for all taxicabs; and 
(10)  The average taxicab lease rate for a taxicab for one 24-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 15, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-166. - Conduct of drivers. 
(a)  A driver shall use the most direct available route on all trips unless the passenger specifically requests to change the route. A driver shall be able to provide a reasonable and prudent amount of change, and if correct change is not available, no additional charge will be made to the passenger in attempting to secure the change. If demanded by the passenger, the driver shall deliver to the person paying for the hiring of the same, at the time of such payment, a receipt therefore in legible writing, containing the trade name of the permit holder, the company number and the driver's name, showing upon such receipt all items for which a charge is made, the total amount paid and the date of payment. 
(b)  A driver who occupies a taxicab stand shall occupy it at the end of the line and move into the first out position on the stand in orderly, single file. Once obtaining the first out or loading position, he or she shall accept the first request for transportation, except that a driver shall not be obligated to accept trips terminating beyond the City limits. Such taxicab stands shall be for exclusive use by City permitted taxicabs. The parking on such taxicab stands by a vehicle that is not a City permitted taxicab shall be prima facie evidence of a violation. 
(c)  Each driver shall keep a trip report as required by this article. Each driver shall, on a daily basis, submit said trip reports to the permit holder, except for drivers who lease the vehicle(s) from the permit holder for a period longer than one day may submit the trip reports at the end of the lease period or weekly, whichever is shorter. All trip reports shall be at all times open to inspection by the vehicle for hire administrator. 
(d)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any person, without being authorized by the City or without having made a prior agreement to provide vehicle for hire services to a specific patron, offers to engage in any business, trade, or commercial transaction involving the rendering to another person of any vehicle for hire services. Unlawful solicitation occurs when a driver solicits passengers: 
(1)  From a location other than the driver's compartment, or the immediate vicinity of his or her vehicle for hire; 
(2)  In a way that annoys or obstructs the movement of a person, or follows any person for the purpose of unlawful soliciting; 
(3)  In a loud, boisterous or annoying manner of voice, or by sign, or in any other annoying manner; or 
(4)  By paying an employee of another business to solicit passengers for or give preferential treatment in directing passengers to the driver's vehicles for hire. 
(e)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a person to solicit vehicle for hire services at any local airport, hotel, motel, bed and breakfast, restaurant, retail or wholesale facility, government facility or center, any entertainment facility or center, transportation facility or center, or any other location of public gathering. 
(f)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to use obscene or profane language, or to be abusive to passengers. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 16, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-167. - Permit holder general responsibilities. 
(a)  A permit holder shall maintain on file for inspection by the City the names of all employees, drivers, their addresses, telephone numbers and driver license numbers. A permit holder shall maintain a file of all complaints received for inspection by the City. Permit holders are responsible for the actions of their employees when on-duty. 
(b)  A permit holder is responsible for the conduct of its drivers. The permit holder is also responsible for the condition of all of its vehicles and equipment operated as vehicles for hire. Actions of drivers or employees in violation of this article shall be imputed to the permit holder whose responsibility it shall be to ensure compliance. 
(c)  All permit holders shall maintain a place of business within the City limits, from which they conduct their operations and shall comply with applicable provisions of the City's Land Development Code. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 17, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-168. - General prohibitions relative to drivers. 
(a)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, or drive with the intent to pick up passengers, originate one-way transportation, or provide return service for non-continuous transportation, within the jurisdictional limits or upon the public streets of the City without a permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(b)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any permit holder or any person to operate, cause to be operated, allow to be operated or drive a vehicle for hire in or upon any street unless and until such person driving the vehicle shall have first obtained a driver's permit. 
(c)  It is prohibited and unlawful for the permit holder or driver to permit any person to accompany or use such vehicle for, or to direct, take or transport, any other person with knowledge or reasonable cause to believe that the purpose of such directing, taking or transporting is to accomplish a criminal activity. 
(d)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any person to reproduce, alter, manufacture, use, display, or otherwise employ any facsimile or reproduction of the permits provided for in this article. 
(e)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a hotel, motel, or restaurant, their agents or employees, or any skycaps or bellmen to offer or pay any money or other gratuity including money, commonly referred to as "turkey money," to a permit holder or a driver as consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger or passengers from one hotel, motel, or restaurant to another hotel, motel, or restaurant, or from a particular vehicle classification to another. 
(f)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a hotel, motel, or restaurant, their agents or employees, or skycaps or bellmen to receive or accept any money or other gratuity including money, commonly referred to as "turkey money," from a permit holder or driver as consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger or passengers from a transportation company or particular classification of vehicle for hire to another permit holder company, driver, or other classification of vehicle for hire service. 
(g)  Whenever any taxicab is occupied by a passenger or passengers the driver shall not permit any other person to occupy or ride in such taxicab if the original passenger or passengers object thereto. If a child under 14 years of age is the original passenger, no other passenger shall be permitted in such taxicab without the consent of the parent or guardian of the original passenger. 
(h)  It is prohibited and unlawful for any person to solicit patronage for a vehicle for hire in a loud or annoying tone of voice, or by any sign or in any manner to annoy any person or to obstruct the movement of any person. It is prohibited and unlawful for a person to follow or touch another person or the luggage or belongings of another person for the purpose of soliciting service without the consent of that other person. 
(i)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to refuse or neglect to transport any orderly person, upon request, unless the vehicle for hire is already engaged or forbidden by the provisions of this article. Nothing herein shall prohibit the requirement of prepayment or deposit by a driver from a passenger. 
(j)  All drivers shall comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of any passenger as to the speed of travel and the route to be taken. 
(k)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to continue on duty for more than 12 hours of active driving time or more than 16 hours of on-duty time during any 24-hour period. Each driver shall record the time of commencing active duty and the times of ending active duty on the driver manifest. 
(l)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to use cigarettes or cigars while transporting a passenger. The use of tobacco products by a driver is prohibited and unlawful by any passenger(s) while in a vehicle for hire, if so ordered by the driver. 
(m)  Every driver shall thoroughly search the interior of each vehicle for hire at the termination of each trip for any article of value that may be left in the vehicle for hire by a passenger. An article found in a vehicle for hire shall immediately be returned the passenger who left the article. If the owner of the article is not known or unable to be located, the driver shall deposit the article with the permit holder at the end of the driver's tour of duty. The permit holder shall file a written notice with the City within 24 hours, describing the article, date and time of loss, and the origin and destination of the trip of the passenger who lost the article. 
(n)  When requested by a passenger, every driver shall give a legible receipt showing the permit holder's name, the driver's name, the vehicle number and any item for which a charge was made. The receipt shall also include that total amount paid and the date of such payment. 
(o)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver or any other person to solicit passengers for a vehicle for hire except when sitting in the driver's seat of the vehicle for hire or while standing within five feet of the vehicle for hire. 
(p)  It is prohibited and unlawful for the driver of a vehicle for hire to receive or discharge a passenger while impeding the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic. Drivers shall receive and discharge passengers in appropriate taxicab stands, loading zones and curbsides out of the flow of traffic. Drivers shall discourage passengers from entering and exiting vehicle for hire while stopped at traffic signals and in travel lanes and shall be responsible for any and all occurrences relating to such stops. 
(q)  Drivers may communicate with dispatchers and a potential passenger(s) by portable telephone communication. However, a driver shall not pick up or transport any passenger without first notifying his or her dispatcher of the trip and recording the trip as required by this article. Single unit drivers are not required to notice a dispatcher, but are required to record the trip. 
(r)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to operate a vehicle for hire, whether on duty or off duty, with any alcoholic beverage, whether opened or unopened, in the passenger compartment of the vehicle for hire. The provisions of this article do not prohibit the possession of an alcoholic beverage in the possession of a bona fide passenger. It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to allow a passenger to violate City or State laws regarding alcoholic beverages while in their vehicle for hires. 
(s)  It is prohibited and unlawful for a driver to permit more persons to be transported in a vehicle for hire at any one time than the seating capacity of such vehicle allows, as established by the vehicle manufacturer. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 18, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-169. - Suspension or revocation of permits. 
(a)  Whenever there is reasonable cause to believe that a permit holder or driver is violating, or has violated, the provisions of this article, the vehicle for hire administrator may initiate enforcement proceedings. The permit holder or driver shall be advised in writing, of the date, time and place of a hearing on the matter, mailed to the address on file with the vehicle for hire administrator, no later than 15 days prior to the date of the hearing. Failure to appear shall result in an automatic suspension or revocation of the permit, and may be grounds for revocation of said permit(s). The vehicle for hire administrator shall conduct the hearing. 
(b)  As may be permitted by controlling state or federal law, any citation issued for a violation may result in the immediate removal and impoundment of the vehicle by the City. The vehicle shall be released to the owner upon payment of any tow, storage, inspection costs, and any other fines or penalties. 
(c)  The vehicle for hire administrator may temporarily suspend any permitted vehicle for hire upon finding that a vehicle is unsafe or the observation of a patent defect of the vehicle for the transportation of the traveling public. The suspension shall take effect immediately upon notice to the driver by issuance of a notice of suspension. The vehicle for hire administrator shall affix a decal to both door-sides of the vehicle which states that the vehicle is suspended pending further investigation and correction of safety and/or equipment violations, and that the vehicle shall not transport any person for hire. The decal shall remain affixed to the vehicle until either the permit holder corrects the safety and/or equipment violations and has the vehicle inspected by the City, and pays the reinstatement fee, or successfully appeals the determination to the City Manager. The operation of a suspended vehicle or the unauthorized removal or alteration of the decals affixed to the vehicle shall result in revocation of the vehicle permit. 
(d)  The following shall constitute grounds for suspension of a vehicle for hire permit: 
(1)  If a permit holder operates, allows, leases or causes to be operated any vehicle for hire which has been issued a vehicle permit without said vehicle permit affixed to the motor vehicle; 
(2)  If a permit holder charges, receives, or obtains any fare from a passenger that is not strictly consistent with any rates and surcharges approved by the vehicle for hire administrator; 
(3)  If a permit holder charges, receives, or obtains any fare from a passenger that is not consistent with approved rates; 
(4)  If a permit holder gives, leases or borrows to the driver or installs or equips in the interior of the vehicle any electrical device such as radar detector/"fuzz buster," police two-way or similar scanners, or two-way radio frequency monitors; 
(5)  If a permit holder fails to have provided in the vehicle for hire a printed schedule of the current adopted rates and/or surcharges available at all times for inspection in all vehicles for hire; 
(6)  If a permit holder fails to keep and file the applicable trip reports; 
(7)  If a permit holder tampers with or changes the adjustment of a meter; 
(8)  If a permit holder operates, leases or causes to operate a taxicab with the knowledge that the meter does not accurately register the mileage and the approved rate. Evidence of the breaking of an official meter seal of the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services shall constitute prima facie evidence that a meter does not accurately register the mileage and rate; 
(9)  If a permit holder fails to equip and maintain every vehicle for hire with an operational two-way radio or comparable communication devices such that office dispatchers may immediately and effectively notify drivers of requests for service, and such that drivers may immediately and effectively request assistance should assistance be needed; 
(10)  If a permit holder has in its possession at its place of business, dispatch operation or in any building or vehicle under its control and possession any device used for the monitoring of a competitor's radio frequency; 
(11)  If a permit holder fails to have permanently posted in a place with a view to the general public within the interior and on each door-side of the outside of each vehicle for hire, the schedule of the current adopted rates, charges and/or surcharges; 
(12)  If a permit holder operates, leases, or causes to be operated a vehicle for hire that does not comply with any of the safety and equipment standards; 
(13)  If the City Council adopts any rate or surcharge for the particular category of vehicle for hire and a permit holder fails to post the informational sign or decal; 
(14)  If a permit holder operates, leases, or causes to operate a vehicle for hire under a trade name, color scheme or logo not approved; 
(15)  If a permit holder offers or pays any money or other gratuity including money, commonly referred to as "turkey money," to a hotel, motel, or restaurant, their agents or employees, or skycaps or bellmen, as consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger or passengers from a classification of vehicle for hire, transportation company, permit holder or drivers to its company or drivers; 
(16)  If a permit holder receives or accepts any money or other gratuity including money, commonly referred to as "turkey money," from a hotel, motel, or restaurant, their agents or employees, or skycaps or bellmen, as consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger or passengers from a hotel, motel, or restaurant to another hotel, motel, or restaurant; 
(17)  If a permit holder intentionally or knowingly misleads, by any act or word, a passenger or potential passenger about: 
a.  The time or place of arrival or departure of a train, airplane, any vehicle for hire or bus; 
b.  The location of any building or place, or the distance between two points; 
c.  The cost or amount of the trip; or 
d.  Information on the cost, availability or quality of another permit holder or driver; 
(18)  If a permit holder operates, or causes to be operated, a permitted vehicle for hire in a non-permitted classification; 
(19)  If a permit holder fails to require and enforce the driver dress code; 
(20)  If a permit holder provides, leases, gives, borrows or uses a taxicab top light, sign, or other roof device in a non-taxicab vehicle for hire; 
(21)  If a permit holder fails to supply the City with a current automobile liability insurance certificate or binder; 
(22)  If a permit holder engages in the unlawful solicitation of passengers; or 
(23)  If the permit holder otherwise violates the provisions of this article. 
(e)  The following shall constitute grounds for revocation of the vehicle for hire permit: 
(1)  If the permit holder fails to provide the insurance required whether by a lapse in coverage or coverage below the minimum amount; 
(2)  If, at the end of a suspension period, the violation or violations have not been corrected, or proof thereof has not been submitted to or accepted by the vehicle for hire administrator, the vehicle for hire permit will be automatically revoked; 
(3)  If a vehicle for hire permit is suspended three or more times in one 365-day period; 
(4)  If the permit holder, its agent or employee operates or causes to be operated a vehicle which is the subject of a suspended vehicle permit; or 
(5)  The permit holder's violations of this article are so pervasive or egregious that revocation is necessary to protect the public interest. 
(f)  The following shall constitute grounds for suspension of a driver's permit: 
(1)  If a driver who operates any vehicle for hire fails to visibly display his/her permit on his/her outer garment or in such vehicle at all times when on duty; 
(2)  If a driver charges, receives, or obtains any fare from a passenger that is not consistent with the rates and surcharges approved by the City; 
(3)  If a driver is in possession of, or it is located within the interior of the vehicle, any electrical device such as radar detector/"fuzz buster," police two-way or similar scanners, or two-way radio frequency monitors. 
(4)  If a driver fails to have printed schedules of the current adopted rates and/or surcharges available at all times for inspection in all vehicles for hire; 
(5)  If a driver fails to keep updated trip reports; 
(6)  If a driver operates a vehicle for hire with any passenger or occupant when the meter is in the non-calculating position, except when operating on a hourly or trip rate; 
(7)  If a driver tampers with or changes the adjustment of a meter; 
(8)  If a driver operates a taxicab with knowledge that the meter does not accurately register the mileage and the rate as set by the City. Evidence of the breaking of an official meter seal of the Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services shall constitute prima facie evidence that a meter does not accurately register the mileage and rate; 
(9)  If a driver operating any vehicle for hire fails to produce his/her driver permit upon demand of any passenger, the vehicle for hire administrator, code enforcement officer, or a Law Enforcement Officer; 
(10)  If a driver smokes a cigarette, cigar, pipe or other tobacco substance in the vehicle while such vehicle is occupied by a passenger, unless the passenger(s) consents otherwise; 
(11)  If a driver allows or permits any person not a passenger, other than the driver him/herself, to occupy the vehicle for hire while it is hired; 
(12)  If a driver operates one or more vehicles for hire for more than 12 cumulative hours within any continuous 24-hour period; 
(13)  If a driver offers or pays any money or other gratuity including money, commonly referred to as "turkey money," to a hotel, motel, or restaurant, their agents or employees, skycaps or bellmen as consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger or passengers from one transportation company, or particular category of vehicle for hire to another, permit holder, driver, or other classification of vehicle for hire services to the driver's company or vehicle; 
(14)  If a driver receives or accepts any money or other gratuity including money, commonly referred to as "turkey money," from a hotel, motel, or restaurant, their agents or employees, or skycaps or bellmen, as consideration for diverting or attempting to divert a passenger or passengers from a hotel, motel, or restaurant to another hotel, motel, or restaurant; 
(15)  If a driver intentionally or knowingly misleads, by any act or word, a passenger or potential passenger about: 
a.  The time or place of arrival or departure of a train, airplane, any vehicle for hire or bus; 
b.  The location of any building or place, or the distance between locations; 
c.  The cost or amount of the trip; or 
d.  Information on the cost, availability or quality of another permit holder or driver; 
(16)  Except as provided in this article, if a driver allows the vehicle for hire to remain, park or occupy any space on the streets for the transaction of business other than the picking up of passengers and letting out of passengers; 
(17)  If a driver, operates, or causes to operate, the permitted vehicle for hire in a classification of vehicle for hire service which is not the category authorized by the vehicle permit; 
(18)  If the driver violates the possession of an improper sign or top light; 
(19)  If a driver fails to provide the most current application information to the vehicle for hire administrator; 
(20)  If a driver violates any of the provisions regulating conduct of taxicab stands; 
(21)  If a driver issues receipts as required by this article; 
(22)  If a driver wrongfully terminates or refuses a trip for any reason; 
(23)  If a driver engages in the unlawful solicitation of passengers; 
(24)  If a driver directs obscene, profane or abusive behavior toward his/her passenger(s); 
(25)  If a driver otherwise violates the provisions of this article. 
(g)  The following shall constitute grounds for revocation of the driver's permit: 
(1)  If a driver is suspended three or more times in one 365-day period; 
(2)  If a driver willfully alters, defaces, obliterates or destroys any driver's permit issued herein, or causes the same to be defaced, obliterated or destroyed; 
(3)  If a driver who has had his or her driver's permit suspended operates a vehicle for hire while under suspension; 
(4)  If a driver is convicted of any of the crimes referred to in this article; 
(5)  If the driver's violations of this article are so pervasive or egregious that revocation is necessary to protect the public interest. 
(h)  If the vehicle for hire administrator suspends a permit, the vehicle for hire administrator shall set a time certain for the period of suspension which shall provide reasonable opportunity for the permit holder to contest the suspension. During the period of suspension the driver shall not operate any vehicle for hire. If the permit holder contests suspension and requests a hearing before the City Attorney, the City Attorney shall hold the hearing and make findings of fact and conclusions of law and report same to the City Manager who shall determine whether the suspension should implemented and, if so, to what extent. 
(i)  If the City Manager revokes a permit, the revocation may be: 
(1)  Conditional and affording the permittee an opportunity to provide further information or take other action which may cure the offense(s) and dissolve the revocation; or 
(2)  Final. 
(j)  Decisions of the City Manager shall be final decisions, shall not be reviewed by the City Council by appeal, and shall constitute the final agency action of the City with respect to the decision. Any review of the decision shall be made by writ for petition for certiorari to the circuit court as provided by law. Suspension or revocation actions shall specify the terms and conditions thereof. 
(k)  Notwithstanding and without limiting the general or specific enforcement authority, any violation of any section of this article by either a driver or permit holder shall subject the driver or permit holder to any other code enforcement remedies available to the City. 
(l)  During the period of suspension or revocation the permittee shall not operate, or cause to have operated or allow the operation of a vehicle for hire. 
(m)  The reinstatement fee for a suspended permit shall be established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 19, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-170. - Compliance with article required. 
It is prohibited and unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this article, or to operate or allow to be operated vehicles for hire within the City unless a permit has been issued for its operation. This article shall not apply to vehicles for hire that enter the City solely to drop off passengers if the vehicle for hire is properly licensed by the jurisdiction in which the vehicle for hire picked up the passenger(s) and in which the said trip originated. A permit shall be required whenever a vehicle for hire picks up passengers within the City to originate one or two-way transportation. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 20, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-171. - Designation of regulatory personnel. 
The City Manager shall designate City personnel who shall be responsible for the administration of this article. Enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the City Manager and his or her designated City employees. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 21, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-172. - Vehicle resembling a vehicle for hire. 
It is prohibited and unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle, which is not a licensed vehicle for hire, with painting or markings that would cause a reasonable person to believe that such vehicle is a vehicle for hire. A vehicle for hire that ceases to be authorized as a vehicle for hire shall have its colors and markings removed, changed, or altered so as not to resemble a vehicle for hire before any operation in the City and may not be visible from any public way, until such removal, change, or alteration, is completed. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 22, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-173. - Defrauding vehicle for hire. 
It is prohibited and unlawful for any person who engages, uses, employs or hires a vehicle for hire to then fail or refuse to pay the required fare with intent to cheat and defraud the driver. This Section not only applies to intra-City trips, but also to legally licensed taxicabs from other jurisdictions that enter the City to reach a destination, where the failure or refusal to pay occurs within the City. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 23, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-174. - Administrative rules. 
The City Manager is hereby authorized to adopt administrative rules that he or she deems necessary and appropriate to implement the provisions of this article to include, but not be limited to, rules relating to the issuance of temporary permits. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 24, 7-5-05)  
Sec. 44-175. - Violations of article/penalties. 
This article may be enforced by the City through any enforcement process available under law and exercising any legal remedy available under law. It is unlawful and prohibited for any person to violate any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-32, § 25, 7-5-05)  
ARTICLE V. - TRAFFIC LIGHT SAFETY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 06-24, §§ 1—15, adopted Dec. 19, 2006, amended the Code by adding provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included herein as §§ 44-201—44-215.  Subsequently, section 2 of Ord. No. 2010-09, amended art. V in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art V, §§ 44-201—44-215, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 06-24, adopted Dec. 19, 2006. 
 
Sec. 44-201. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to authorize the use of traffic infraction detectors to promote compliance with red light signal directives as set forth in this article, and to adopt a civil enforcement system for red light signal violations, in accord with general law, including Chapter 2010-80, Laws of Florida (2010) (the "Mark Wandall Traffic Safety Act" or "Act") and the amendments to the Act, set forth in Chapter 2013-XX. This article will supplement law enforcement personnel in the enforcement of red light signal violations and shall not prohibit law enforcement from issuing a citation for a red light signal violation in accordance with normal statutory traffic enforcement techniques. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, § 2, 7-20-10; Ord. No. 2013-04, § 2, 7-2-13)  
Sec. 44-202. - Use of traffic infraction detectors. 
The City shall utilize traffic infraction detectors pursuant to general law as a means of monitoring compliance with the state laws related to traffic control signals, while assisting law enforcement personnel in the enforcement of such laws, which are designed to protect and improve public health, safety and welfare. This section shall not supersede, infringe, curtail or impinge upon state laws related to red light signal violations or conflict with such laws. The City may utilize traffic infraction detectors as an ancillary deterrent to traffic control and traffic signal violations and thereby reduce accidents and injuries associated with such violations.
